Of course, you can use your own pieces and strategy cards to interfere with other players, but it is also very effective to make use of the fact that the secret orders are undisclosed to encourage other players to interfere without getting your hands dirty.

In addition, since all players want to have a useful base of troops and treasure, alliances will be formed early in the game, either by using pieces and strategy cards to fight for the base, or by spontaneously forming alliances to share the base. There are no penalties for betraying alliances, so don't hesitate to betray an alliance if you think you can fulfill a secret order and get closer to victory.

Repeatable and fun!

At the start of the game, in addition to the secret mission card, seven different hero cards are dealt to the player in public, and each of the seven heroes has various characteristics: some are good at power play by sending out many pieces, some are good at trick play by making use of strategy cards, and some are good at slowly accumulating strength in a safe area. Since seven types of secret mission cards are combined with these unique heroes, the fighting style changes every time, so you can enjoy the game for a long time without getting bored.

Also, the initial placement of the hero pieces is determined by the hero cards. It is quite advantageous if the initial placement is close to the base which is the victory condition. However, if other players think that the victory condition is too early, you will be attacked from many directions or receive a concentrated fire of strategy cards, and it is not easy to win. Try to avoid letting your opponent know your victory condition.

On the other hand, you will be at a disadvantage if the base that is the victory condition is far from your initial placement. Use all possible means to achieve a victory on thin ice, such as boldly attacking and destroying the opponent's heroic pieces, making alliances with other players using the opponent with an advantage on the board as a common virtual enemy, or forcing them to fight each other.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Hidden Victory Points

name: A Day in Paris
description:
You and a friend are visiting Europe, and have different ideas about how to explore Paris’ many tourist attractions in the single day you have. It may sound easy, but Paris is a major city, bustling with tourists and traffic. Your normal means of traversing the connections between attractions is the hop-on-hop-off bus, but if you want to travel faster you can take an expensive taxi from time to time. At each attraction you’ll enjoy spending time exploring, sometimes for a short period and sometimes a longer stay. You’ll be distracted by delicious French pastries, however, and all day long you won’t be able to ignore any patisserie you see. Sip an espresso with your treats, but don’t forget that your goal is to have a better sightseeing experience than your opponent – and both quantity and quality will count toward victory!

GAMEPLAY
On a player’s turn, he/she may take one of the following actions:

• Play one or more cards to travel along the connection lines on the board, from one attraction to another.
• Play one card to explore an attraction.
• Discard one card.

There are three types of connections between attractions: short, medium and long. To move along a connection, a player plays one or more cards from his hand and uses its time symbols to meet the connection’s requirements. Once at an attraction, a player can explore it via melding a matching card from his hand. A few special actions and "long waits" at some attractions add randomness and flavor.

COMPONENTS
• 1 Game Board
• 54 Action Cards
• 20 Wooden Cubes
• 1 Set of Chits
• 2 Player Tokens
• 1 Rules booklet

-description from designer
mechanics: Hand Management, Point to Point Movement

name: SALBAGE
description:
SALBAGE is a 2 player abstract postcard game from Japan. The postcard has the rules on one side, and the playing area on the other (two are sold in a pack).

Each player has three dice of their own colour. They take turns rolling and placing the dice on the 3*3 grid. Each space has an instruction, which allow the player to change the dice number or move it around.

The winner is the first player to get all three of their dice to show all odd or all even numbers.
user summary

name: Hook'em Champ
description:
Grab some Hooks and swing your pole it’s time for the Hook'em Champ tournament. The lake has been stocked with 9 unique types of fish. Are you up to the challenge? Can you become the next Hook'em Champ?

In Hook'em champ 2-4 players will use dice as hooks. You have 3 actions per turn to Collect, Cast, and Catch. You may Collect Hooks from the Tackle Box, Cast (roll) to determine Depth/Area, and Catch as many fish as you have Hooks/Actions for. As fish are caught, the lake gets restocked. When there are no more fish to stock the lake the tournament will end. Keep an eye out for items and extra ways to get bonuses. Schooling fish with lake sharks can earn a lot of extra bonus points!

The player with the highest points at the end of the game wins. Go Get’em Champ!

-description from designer

name: Rivalen der Piste
description:
This game is about a Grand Prix race. Every player sports 3 cars. With special dice (all six-sided displaying different numbers for slow, moderate and fast movement) you move your cars. First you choose the dice you want to roll, then you assign the results to your 3 cars. I's a good idea to reduce speed in track curves to avoid beeing set back. A special effect occurs when rolling a 6 with the moderate die. You roll again and add the result to the previous roll.

Victory points are given for the cars reaching the finish line. The player with the highest score of his 3 cars wins the game.

This game was reimplemented (with several changes and additional rules) in 1988 by PS from Hans im Glück.

—user summary
mechanics: Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Team AG
description:
Players complete 2 different games one after the other. The first one let the players act in competition to their own colleagues and outside competitors, the second one makes the players build a team to act together against outside competitors.

Game components are a map, player-tokens, outside competitor tokens and cards for the movement of the tokens. Players have to move their own and the competitor tokens in direction of the target field. If the value of outside competitor tokens exceeds the value of the players tokens on one field, the players tokens are send back to the starting field. In the first game a single player wins the game, in the second game all players lose or win, depending on the value of their tokens compared to the value of the outside competitor tokens.

—user summary

name: ドゼクス (CODE6)
description:
ドゼクス (CODE6) is a word deduction game from Japan for 3 players only (more can play if you provide extra chips).

Players are trying to deduce a word or expression from just a few letters laid out. The game has a deck of letter cards showing both the Roman letter and Japanese characters. But the deck represents the normal Hiragana sounds, so only 15 Roman letters are used including the vowel A. This enables players to construct Japanese words in steps that are more or less obvious.

Players declare a theme to their word and lay out cards in a crossword style, one by one. Players score points for correctly guessing words from limited steps.

The game was revised as Code 6+, with more components added, including hint cards. These allow the game to be more subtle and harder to crack. The guessing players can ask for hints, using six specific hint cards. These hints apply to parts of the secret word, or the whole meaning. The word deck was revised to remove dice symbols from the letter cards. Crib sheets of suitable words were included with the game to assist players.

The game relies upon a good knowledge of Hiragana words and would be difficult for non-speakers of Japanese.
user summary
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Puzzle, Word Game
publishers: Joynt Game Factory (ジョイントゲームファクトリー)

name: Vamos a Brasília
description:
The new capital of Brazil - Brasilia - began to be built in 1956 and was inaugurated in 1960. During this period it generated great international interest and many people ventured through the central highlands of Brazil, then remote and uninhabited, to get to know the city under construction. This game tries to capture that trend.

Players draw a card that will determine the place of departure and the initial means of transportation (plane, train or car). From that point they move their pawns to other cities that are connected by the same means of transport (for example, if you travel by plane, you can only move to another city with an airport, only if you take 3 or 6 on the die).

Some cities allow the player to change the mode of transport, in some others players will only arrive with the exact number in the data and in others they will receive a card with penalties or rewards.

The first player to arrive in Brasilia is the winner.

name: Tenniscrack Poppy
description:
Two players meet for a short tennis match on a gameboard. The gamefield grid on each side is made of 25(5x5) squares, where you move your pawn and the tennis ball. Players roll 3 six-sides dice and have to use 2 added results for the movement of their pawn and the movement of the ball. First your movement points are used to get your pawn beside the ball. The remaining movement points must be used to move the ball into the opponents side. Once a player can't perform these 2 actions (because of point shortage or to many points) the opponent scores a victory-point. The first player to score 6 victory-points wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: At the Height of Battle
description:
This is our brand new game based on Asian Naval Warfare rules written by David Manley. The game allows you to replay battles between the fleets of Korea, Japan and China, focusing on the Imjin War between Korea and Japan in the 16th century. The era of Admiral Yi Sun Shin and his famous Turtle Ships.

—description from the publisher

name: Maratony Polskie
description:
Lead your team of racers through the season and win on the road running. Play with addiction and drag them into the world of running.

The game is intended for 2-4 players. At the beginning of the game, each of them draws a 4-person team of competitors, who must be in the entire 2012 season, consisting of 10 randomly selected runs. and ... we try to take the best places at the finish line. Three victory points all over the place in each of the award-winning games. Three victory points in the game. Three victory points for the entire season.

The game contains a few flavors - one of them is a book with the profiles of the players, with a place for their autographs. When we play with the game and we have our hand autographed, his card in the game will be stronger! In line with our team stronger also in the real world! Which we have already completed in the real world!

name: Snowsmash Clan
description:
As the director of a winter sport called "Snow Smash", you lead three clan members to compete against rival teams.

Players use two actions, "Step" and "Smash", to move around the field, which becomes narrower with time, and send snowballs to predict the whereabouts of opponents hiding somewhere in the same field.

If the snowball hits, you get points!
Use the unique smash gadgets called "Arum" to get more points than your rivals!
As the director of a winter sport called "Snow Smash", you lead three clan members to compete against rival teams.

Players use two actions, "Step" and "Smash", to move around the field, which becomes narrower with time, and send snowballs to predict the whereabouts of opponents hiding somewhere in the same field.

—description from the publisher (translated)

name: Everyone's a Critic: A game of drawing sketchy things
description:
Everyone’s A Critic is a fun adult drawing game that brings artists and amateurs together to compete for the most hilarious drawing.
HOW TO PLAY: Players take turns as “The Critic”. The Critic draws a card and reads it out loud. The other players have 60 seconds to draw the best image that comes to mind. The first player to win three rounds wins it all. Players: 3 - 10+ | Time: 30 - 90 min | Ages: 17+
Some of the drawings will be lighthearted like draw your spirit animal, others will be sketchy (pun intended) like draw the person most likely to fart during sex.


There are five card types: Draw This, Questions, Eyes Closed, Speed Round, and Wild Cards.

The game includes 170 sketchy drawing prompts, 10 blank cards for your own ridiculous ideas, 10 draw pads, 10 pencils, a sand timer, and a pair of very stylish glasses?


—description from the publisher

name: Vengeance of the Gods
description:
The world burns with divine wrath in a new sacred war. Test your mettle in Vengeance of the Gods, where modern warfare meets the power of the ancient gods in a challenging area control strategy wargame. Choose one of 12 ancient deities to worship, each one granting unique and powerful abilities. Master the skies with the might of Zeus or fool your enemy with one of Loki's mischievous tricks. With the gods on your side, it's a race against other players for territory and resources and you fight to rule the world. Will you dominate your enemies and prove you divine right or will you fall before the might of other deities?

Theme:
Modern warfare with ancient gods.

Game-play:
Each player builds a modern army (soldiers, artillery, tanks, planes) while also worshipping an ancient god. When the gods are happy they grant players powerful abilities to help them wage war.

Battles are conducted using dice. The game comes with 30 dice so large battles are conducted quickly.

Goal:
Each player starts the game with a town. For short games (60-120mins) the first player to take control of 3 towns wins.

For longer conquest game (120-180mins) the first player to control 4 continents wins.

—description from the designer
categories: Ancient, Dice, Modern Warfare, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: シャオパイロン (Xiao Pylon)
description:
シャオパイロン (Xiao Pylon) 小白龍 (Small White Dragon) is a game from Japan with players trying to collect scales from a dragon by entertainment.

The dragon starts in the middle of the chequered board and the players' tokens set up near the dragon. Players then use hand cards to see who moves, and try to get their token next to the dragon to collect scale tokens. Then a card is turned up to move the dragon. The board is wrap around, and the dragon can move diagonally, but not onto a player.

The game uses a butting mechanism. Players chose a card in secret, reveal together, and when cards are matched, those players cancel each other out. The highest clear number wins, but players also have fan cards. If a high number wins, a fan card can also move. But if multiple fan cards are played, they also cancel each other.

After 6 rounds, the player with the most scales is the winner.

The game includes rules for 2 players.
user summary

The publisher says:
An old story. The scales of the White Dragon were very beautiful and highly prized. However, it is said that anything that touches the body of the White Dragon will be cursed and unhappy. You have found the temple where the White Dragon lives. A small white dragon lived in the temple. Then Hakuryu spoke to me. "Do you want scales? If so, entertain me. By the way, scales are swelling. Who is the most daring and lucky one in the swelling? Then, the color of your eyes changed and the battle for scales began. Who can get the most scales?

The simple rule is that the person who collects the scales and wins the most in all 6 rounds, but the card selection for each round is very troublesome, and the tricky moving small white dragon determines the outcome of the game. An unusual card butting game that uses square boards and pieces.
publisher's summary
publishers: Chicken Dice Games (チキンダイスゲームズ)

name: Crazy Cultists: The Dark Powers Expansion
description:
You wanted dark powers...and now you got 'em! Or at least you CAN get them. Earn the Dark One's favor to be granted powerful new abilities in the form of Dark Powers Cards and start wreakin' some freakin' havoc!
​
Adds 13 unique and super-powerful Hijinx Cards that are used to thoroughly fracture your opponents' favor with the Dark One.

—description from the publisher

name: Nusubito
description:
Nusubito is a two player hidden movement game in which one player will take on the role of the Thief; a ninja-like character leaping across temple rooftops in search of a hidden treasure. The other player will control the Mists, spirits who guard the temple complex.

The game is played over a series of Day and Night cycles, with three rounds per day, and one round per night.

During the day, the Thief will be secretly leaping from temple to temple looking for clues about the hidden treasure’s whereabouts, whilst the Mists spread across the board in search of the intruder!

During the night, each side will get the chance to gather resources.

Play ends when either the Thief finds the Treasure, or the Mists capture the Thief!
categories: Abstract Strategy, Deduction, Print & Play, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Action Points, Deduction, Grid Movement, Hidden Movement

name: Die Brücke
description: A game with a bridge over a water bath in which players try to push each others pieces off the bridge into the water.

name: Indian Knaves
description:
Rules for two players:

Use one deck of normal face cards. Remove the jokers. No table talk. Trick-taking game like rook, but number of cards won matters rather than certain cards having points.

One player is the dealer. The other player is the trump caller. The dealer shuffles the deck and the other player cuts the deck.

The dealer deals 5 cards in a row face down to the trump caller.

The trump caller looks at their cards privately and chooses a trump suit based on just those 5 cards.

Once trump is called, the dealer then deals 5 cards face down to himself. (The 5 cards dealt to each player will be part of their hand.)

The dealer then deals 8 face down cards in front of each player that nobody can look at.

The dealer then deals 8 face up cards on top of the face down cards that everyone can see. (One face up card on top of each face down card.)

The dealer then deals 3 cards in a row to the trump caller's hand, then 3 cards in a row into his own hand.

The dealer then deals 2 cards in a row to the trump caller's hand, then 2 cards in a row into his own hand.

There should now be:
10 cards in each player's hand that only the player holding them can see
8 cards in front of each player that are face down that neither player has seen
8 cards right on top of the face-down cards in front of each player that all players can see
That makes a total of 52 cards in play (the whole deck without jokers).

The trump caller starts the game by choosing a card from either their hand or from the face up cards in front of them.

The other player then plays a card and must follow suit. Highest card number wins. Aces are high. If they cannot follow suit because they don't have that suit either in their hand or face up on the table, they can play anything they want. Trump cards will take the trick in that case and other suits (non-trump and not following suit) lose - just like in Rook.

Whenever a face up card is played, the face down card below it must immediately be turned over and it becomes part of the cards that can be played in subsequent tricks.

Whoever takes that trick keeps those cards and puts them aside and then leads the next trick.

The round ends when all cards in hands, face up, and face down have been played and all tricks taken.

The winner is the player that got the most tricks (most cards). In the case of a tie, the dealer wins since the trump caller has a slight advantage and must take more than half of the cards to win.

To play another round, swap who is dealer and trump caller between each round played. Choose a number of rounds to be won to win the overall game.

Strategy ideas

The game is similar to Rook, but it splits your hand into three parts:
your hand - which only you see
face down cards - which nobody sees
face up cards - which everyone sees

One example of using this knowledge is that if a player doesn't follow suit and plays a face up card which then reveals a face down card that is the suit that was just led, then you know that's the only card of that suit they have and so they must play it if you lead that suit again. There are many other strategies like this that can be used based on the global knowledge of face up cards.

Four players

The game could be modified for four players by using two decks and having the trump caller be the person to the left of the dealer and moving the dealer to the left each round. Notice that there will be two of each card in such a game.

Three players

Just like four players but you could either use one deck and reduce the number of hand cards, face down cards, and face up cards or use two decks and increase the number of cards used for each player.
one deck
hand cards: 4 at the start, then 2 then 1 (instead of 5, 3, and 2)
face down cards: 5
face up cards: 5
You'll have 1 card leftover.
two decks (just double the numbers above - might be too much?)
hand cards: 8 at the start, then 4, then 2
face down cards: 10
face up cards: 10
You'll have 2 cards leftover.

Other notes

This is a combination of two games: one is a game from India who played it with his grandmother, the other is knaves.

It's apparently similar to the ancient card game "Whist", which is where the card game "Bridge" apparently came from and Rook is also similar in some ways.

We've actually played a three-player variant of Rook making the fourth dummy hand split as face down and face up and the dummy's partner plays from the face up cards - kind of like bridge but with face down cards hidden.

—description from the designer

name: Wer baut zuerst sein Haus?
description:
The players have one pawn each, to move around the game board. Movement is determined by a die. After each complete round around the board the player gets a building piece to build his house (a foundation, 4 walls and a roof). If a pawn get on a space already occupied by another pawn , the one who arrived first gets thrown out and has to start the round anew. On the numbered spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

The first player to complete his house wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Samsara
description: Dexterity game in which marbles are placed in holes of a "giant wheel", which thereby changes its center of gravity and causes marbles to fall out. A metal marble particularly unbalances the wheel. The player to place all his marbles in the wheel wins the game.

name: Codicod
description: Player get a hand of five letter tiles and place them on a 8x8 grid to form words and earn points. The letters that are at play can be rotated to form other letters (e.g H is I rotated 90 degrees), and consequently other words. Points are used to purchase new tiles. The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.
mechanics: Hand Management, Spelling, Square Grid, Tile Placement

name: Objective: Survive
description:
This print and play board game is a game where you, the player's plane has crashlanded somewhere in the north Canadian wilderness. You are its only survivor. Your objective is to survive the four weeks it takes for rescue crews to find you.
In order to accomplish this, you must learn to find and manage Food, Water, Wood, and, the most valuable resource, your own health. As the weeks progress the days will get progressively tougher. It is up to you to ensure your own survival in this harsh wilderness.

name: ドルフィンスナップ (Dolphin Snap)
description:
ドルフィンスナップ (Dolphin Snap) is a game from Japan in which players try to compose photos of marine life in an aquarium. The game includes a picture frame and a tripod. Cutouts of dolphins and whales are assembled on vertical stands and process around through dice rolls. Players are trying to get attractive groupings of dolphins in frame at the right time to get their photo. The best composed shots win the most points.

The game has a long blue cord which is placed as a loop on the table. The frame is set up in front of this, and a blue background is put to the rear. Players then throw a number of blue dice into the loop. These determine which marine animals appear. The number and types of dolphins are limited and will not appear all the time. The cutouts are clipped at different levels to blue poles, and these are stuck to small platforms which go alongside the corresponding dice. Looking through the frame, the players can see some creatures in shot, but not all of them. In this way, players compose a shifting three dimensional diorama of sea life passing the frame of the camera.

Players have to chose when to take a good photo. Should they get a quick snap, or wait a bit in case a more interesting creature swims by. Will the enormous whale shark appear at the back? If the dolphins move on, will the players regret the missed chance to get a good picture?

When a player has taken their photo and scored points for it, the next player rolls the dice and continues.

Whilst being a competitive game, the designer's intention is to engage the players in a contemplative experience as they consider their place in the world. The game can be played just as well by a solo player.
user summary

name: 18Rhine
description:
Set in the Rhine River valley, this is much like 18USA and the 1817 branch of 18xx, but has no short shares.

The loans are still present, but have fixed interest each OR, and if the company cannot pay, the company's owner owes 2x what the company would have paid.
mechanics: Connections, Market, Network and Route Building, Stock Holding, Tile Placement

name: こねこのままで (Koneko No Mama De)
description:
こねこのままで is a trick-taking type card game that can be enjoyed by 3 to 6 people.
Players are cat lovers, each with their own cat.
At first, it's a small and cute kitten, but if you pick up the card with a trick, your body will grow!
Let's put out the card well so that the cat does not grow out!
categories: Animals, Card Game, Fantasy, Party Game

name: ティモ (Timo)
description:
ティモ (Timo) is a game from Japan that mimics the videogame Tetris.

The game has a lot of wooden T shapes and two d6 dice and some components to aid play; a base plate, a measuring block and scoring sticks.

The dice are different. One shows the T shape but with a line in different places to show its orientation to the base. The other dice shows 1,1,1,1,2,3.

The rules allow two games, one to play Tetris and one for a balancing game. With the Tetris game, players take turns to roll the dice and place the shapes in a vertical stack, no wider than the base plate.
user summary

name: かけるかな？ (Kakeru ka na?)
description:
かけるかな？ (Kakeru ka na?) is a communication game from Japan. "Do you call it?" was produced in a sealed paper bag, and contains 50 picture cards, and a block of notepaper and 6 pencils.

Players take turns to be the explainer. The explainer takes one of the picture cards in secret and explains what the image is. The other players draw their idea of the shape based upon the description. Once each player has done, they show their drawings and compare them with the picture card. They decide who got closer to the image on the picture card.

If they agree the drawing was close enough to the picture card, the explainer gets 5pts, the drawer gets 3pts, and the other players get 1pt each.

Players take turns to be the explainer. When everyone has been explainer at least once, the scores are totalled up. The player with the most points wins.

The designer suggest ways to make it easier or harder to explain. The explainer should start with describing what the largest part of the image is. For an easier game, allow players to ask questions, let the explainer use their hands, players can use an eraser. To make the game harder, allow only one question each, words only, no eraser. The hardest method limits the players to only 5 minutes and no questions or eraser.

The designer suggests you can draw your own new shapes on the backs of the picture cards, or use a computer (the designer used Paint to make the game). Or if you tire of the game, use the cards as coasters for your drinks!
user summary

name: Mickey Mouse's Pizza Party Game
description:
Players must travel along the board collecting pizzas. The first one to get to the end of the board with 3 pizzas wins.

—user summary

name: Magna Acies! Armies & Battles: Punic and Macedonian Wars
description:
This booklet is the first in a series, entitled Armies and Battles, accompanying MAGNA ACIES! "battle size" rules for 3D wargames for the Ancient age (without the rules, therefore, this booklet serves you little purpose).

We decided to start from the Punic Wars and the Macedonian Wars because these were probably, from a tactical point of view, the most interesting conflicts of Antiquity, which marked (together with Alexander's campaigns) new reference models for Military Art.

During these conflicts, the Romans had to abandon the primitive concept of the simple "attack on the center" to worry about the wings as well, while the phalanx ceased to be the most successful formation of Antiquity: fundamental themes, as you can well understand, decisive for 15 subsequent centuries and even beyond.

This booklet consists essentially of three elements:

three "Quickstart Scenarios" (with attached game tables),
fifteen "Army Lists" (always with attached game tables) and
six "Battle Maps"


—description from the publisher
categories: Ancient, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame

name: O Petróleo é nosso!
description: In the early 1950s, Brazil was agitated by a campaign in favor of the nationalization of the oil industry. This game is based on this spirit: it is a simple game, the players spin the roulette wheel to transport their equipment to the drilling point. When they get there they automatically lose a round and start their progression through the houses corresponding to the land to be drilled. The winner is the first to reach the oil layer with an exact bid.

name: Taxi!: The "Drive as You Please" Traffic Game
description:
In Taxi, you play the role of a taxi driver whose goal is to pick up passengers and deliver them to the airport. All the while, you have to obey the rules of the road. If you are in violation of the driving laws, then you can become targeted by the police.

Players control their taxi plus they control one police car. On your turn, roll two 6 sided dice. You assign one die to yourself and one to your police car. But you also have two optional methods for the roll: you can assign both dice to your police car move, or you can take one of your dice, assign it to your taxi, and DOUBLE it. This represents speeding, which is a violation.

Whenever you break the law, you become vulnerable to being captured by other player's police cars. Other violations include: picking up passengers from the wrong side of the road and going down one way streets the wrong way. If you are caught by police for violating the law, you lose any passengers in your cab, you go to traffic court and pay hefty fines.

Game ends when there are no more passengers to pick up. The taxi driver with the most money wins the game and is obligated to look in a mirror and say "are you lookin at me?".

name: Fire Team Vietnam 2: Platoon Command
description:
Fire Team Vietnam 2: Platoon Command is a Sub-Tactical level game of the Vietnam War, (1965-1975) that places each player in the role of a Company Commander, Sections and Squad of the U.S. Army or Allied Infantry Company against the forces of the National Liberation Front (NLF) (Viet Cong) and the North Vietnam Army (NVA) through various missions in the Vietnam.

These rules are an evolution of Fire Team Vietnam in a Version 2.0, with the aim of simplifying the rules so that it is easier and faster to play.
But also to be able to play at 2 tactical levels with the corresponding rules and maps:

Platoon Command = Sub-tactical , 1 hex = 5 meters, a Game Turn = 1 minute.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board

name: Hvor er den lille kanin
description:
A play-based game for children age 18 months and up.

In this game, an adult player hides a fluffy bunny under one of the six cups, and the child's task is then to find the bunny.

The game has eight suggested play modes, depending on the child's age and development.

name: Lord Of The Drinks: Władca Promili
description:
You are the one they will tell you about

"His last party was like a Predator meeting with Sauron."

Discover the story of the Promila Ruler.

The time has come to go to the Bottom of the Mortuary, to give the Big Eye the Evil Cookie and take it to the Oven of Destiny - where it will be burned, incinerated, stoned, smoked and thus stop the Big Eye, which wants to cover the world with eternal darkness (yes, it has photophobia). Then there will be great joy ... and every joy should be poured out. In this evil plan, you will be disturbed by the cookie guardian - Bloodthirsty York. But don't worry ... if you fail to deliver the Cake to Piecyek, it may be eternal darkness, but you can always pour your sorrows out of despair.

Simple rules are a way to quickly engage your friends.
The rivalry, twists and turns of the Bloodthirsty York guarantee that you will be happy to come back to the game at subsequent events.
Powerful references to "a certain trilogy" will provide you with an additional, abstract dose of humor.
Everything in addition twice - two boards, two types of gameplay, it's twice as crazy party!

name: Jagd auf den Feuerfisch
description:
Divers go on an underwater hunt and must reach the firefish before their opponents in order to win. Whoever wins the respective trick can draw their diver and lay event cards. Each player has a stack of face-down cards and draws the top one. Whoever lays the highest draw card wins the trick and the cards. Then he draws the value of the collected move cards, won event cards he may place beforehand for his own advantage or disadvantage of the opponents. The full number must be drawn, several pieces may stand on one square, the target square must be reached directly, excess points must be drawn backwards.

—user summary
categories: Adventure, Animals, Children's Game, Nautical, Racing

name: ナンバースイッチ (Number Switch)
description:
ナンバースイッチ (Number Switch) is a game from Japan, based upon a local news story. An electronics store was giving away a free Nintendo Switch, but didn't use a sensible method of picking the winning number. As a result, two customers had the numbers either side of the winning number. The game designer used this event as the inspiration for this deduction game.

The game uses a suit of 1-13 cards from a normal deck of playing cards. One player is the retailer, the other players are the customers in the lottery. The retailer shuffles the 13 cards and removes one in secret, which nobody sees.

Then the retailer divides the 12 remaining cards into two piles and sorts them each from low to high numbers, placing them face-down. The players take turns to draw the top card from a pile and after getting three hand cards, a player make declare the hidden card. If they are correct, they win.

If the cards run out and no player has guessed correctly, the retailer can declare a number card that a player has (deducing in reverse). If the player does hold that card in their hand, the retailer wins.

As with other games from Loserdogs, this was produced in a simple ziplock baggie with only a page of rules and 13 playing cards.
user summary

name: Das Froschwanderspiel
description:
The frogs (pawns) migrate from their winter quarters to the spawning water, but the pond is in danger of drying up. The players move their frogs, clean the pond and fill it with water again. The player whose turn it is draws event cards and the frogs move. They have to stop at danger spots and try to roll the number and the solution for the danger. If the attempt is unsuccessful, a dry stone enters the pond, but the other players can help, forego their movement and roll the dice to remove the danger. Once at the pond, the players can now remove dry stones, always according to the number of frogs already present. If there are fewer than 15 dry stones in the pond at the end and there is no toxic waste in the pond, the players have won.

—user summary
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Events, Track Movement

name: Rikki-Tikki-Tavi
description:
"The motto of all the mongoose family is, 'Run and find out'; and Rikki-tikki was a true mongoose."

Based on Rudyard Kipling's short story, Rikki-Tikki-Tavi pits Cobras and Mongooses (or "Mongeese"?) against each other. Rikki-Tikki leads the Mongoose army against Nag and Nagaina and their band of snakes, but be careful when you are scouting through the thick jungle; a harmless snake scout may turn out to be the ruthless Nagaina herself!

Each side seeks to kill the enemy leader using an army of pieces with different abilities. The type of piece is kept secret from your opponent, so you can choose whether to bluff your opponent by keeping your leader brazenly exposed, press your luck with fearless attacks, or strategically cover your pieces with a careful defense.

A modern take on the game of Chess, Rikki-Tikki-Tavi makes each game a thrilling and unique experience that can no longer be "solved", and levels the playing field between enthusiasts and newbies, while still preserving tactical gameplay.

—description from the designer
categories: Abstract Strategy, Bluffing, Deduction, Fighting, Novel-based, Wargame
mechanics: Catch the Leader, Deduction, Grid Movement, Secret Unit Deployment, Square Grid, Variable Set-up

name: The Art of Boxing Clever: Solo Play AI Expansion Pack
description:
The Solo Play AI expansion for The Art of Boxing Clever allows you to pit your wits against three skill levels of AI boxers. Each of the five boxing styles are available to fight against in the form of the 5 boxers from the base game.

Expand your Art of Boxing Clever board game experience with Solo Play. Can you beat a bunch of cards?

—description from the publisher

name: The Art of Boxing Clever: Arcade Mode Expansion Pack
description:
The Arcade mode for The Art of Boxing Clever offers an alternative experience for faster paced gameplay. Perfect for when you are short of time.

Time becomes a factor in your decision making and the original The Art of Boxing Clever damage system is streamlined to create a simplified boxer health bar indicator. All the tactical options are available to you from the original game, but if it's possible this is an even more intense version of the ART of BOXING CLEVER.

—description from the publisher

name: The Art of Boxing Clever: Fighting Dirty Expansion Pack
description:
The Fighting Dirty expansion for the ART of BOXING CLEVER has been designed to add extra spice to the base game by introducing the underhanded tactics and dark arts of fighting dirty in the boxing ring. The expansion offers players new tactics to gain the upper hand over their opponents and inflict maximum damage on their most vulnerable areas.

Sportsmanship is now a factor. Will your boxer be an instigator or a victim? New options are available for you to decide which approach suits your needs.

Last but by no means least, introducing your referee Mr Geoffrey Weller who be on the lookout for any illegal tactics. Boxer's will be warned, deducted points or even disqualified if spotted.

—description from the designer

name: Vaction Spin
description:
Travel to 8 Exotic destinations, with varying prices simulating the variables of real travel. Destinations such as Alaska, Costa Rica, Hawaii, Italy, Mexico, Tahiti.

Object of the game is to travel to as many Destinations within a set time. There are no dice and spinner offers varying prices. Player buys vouchers, for example 'Scuba diving in Tahiti 200 X Spin. If he spins 1, pay $200. If another player spins 8, pay $1,600 for the Same voucher!

This takes into consideration variables such as traveling High vs. low season, Deluxe vs. economy, Number in your party. This is what makes my game Unique, as there are no set prices in travel.

'Travel Ups and Downs' cards add fun surprises. Up: Dream vacation, go to any Destination. Down: Luggage went on its own vacation, Pay $1,500 to the Travel Bonus corner. Player who lands on this space gets all the loot!

—description from the publisher

name: Am Ende des Regenbogens
description:
In this environmental game, players try to prevent greenland from being covered with mud. In his turn, a player reveals a situation card that shows a positive or negative environmental behaviour. In the case of negative behaviour, the bad figure "Schmutzich" is moved towards a target field, in the case of positive behaviour, the good figure "Knud" may be moved towards the target field. In addition, the player rolls the dice and can move his own figure or "Knud" towards the target field. If "Schmutzich" reaches the target field first, mud is placed on grassland, if "Knud" and a player arrive before "Schmutzich", a rainbow piece is placed. The players win together if they manage to lay 4 rainbow pieces. The players lose if "Schmutzich" was able to lay 4 mud pieces.

—user summary
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: バトルアスリート (Battle Athlete)
description:
バトルアスリート (Battle Athlete) is a racing game from Japan. Players are athletes competing in a road race across mountains and valleys. But the course has obstacles and the players push each other around or use items to get the jump on the others. The first to the finish line is the winner.

The race course is made of large tiles placed in a line. The game has a starting tile, and five course tiles, of which four are used, and a finish line. The course tiles have a variety of icons; walls, pits, arrows and objects.

Players choose the turn order, and the last player puts their athlete where they like on the start line, then the next player and so on. In this way, the start player does not get an advantage.

Players roll dice and move their athlete. If they end up on an icon, or push another athlete onto one, the actions are completed.

Pits make a player fall back 2 places and miss a turn. Walls delay players, and arrows push them in the direction of the arrow. The ? icon lets the player draw an object card from the deck. These objects allow the player to make advances, or delay other players, or even change the position of the course tiles.

The first player to reach the finish line wins the race.

The designer Misaki notes that this was one of their earliest designs. It became the third game published by the doujin circle, but had been a car race game sent to a magazine five years previously. The prototype was made 15 years before 2009, making it 1994. The designer thought it was too good a game to waste and brought it back into production in 2009.
user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Biathlon
description:
The players compete as biathletes. They move their pawns with a dice over a circuit with uphills and downhills. The dice are also rolled at the shooting range.
The player who crosses the finish line first wins the game.
Several rule additions, e.g. event cards, risk minimisation when shooting, increased risk of falling when moving downhill and the use of tactical action cards extend the basic game.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Tech Company
description:
This game puts you behind the wheel of one of the most important tech companies in the last century. You will relive the stories of some of the most influential technology innovators in history that paved the way to what we are capable of today. People like Edwin H. Land, a scientist who invented a whole new paradigm in photography with Polaroid, or Nolan Bushnell who executed on the first ever video gaming ideas with Atari, that drove the world into an age of digital video games and personal computers. It will be like being inside an interactive documentary, where you play the founder first person.

You start as a simple tech start-up and through multiple plays you and the story evolve into giving you the responsibility of turning your first product successes into a real tech company that people worship. A company that aims to take over the world with cutting edge inventions by visionary and quirky personalities.

You will attract the best talent, develop prototypes and turn them into mind boggling customer experiences. You will need to compose a sweet spot of skills in product design and engineering, business, management, marketing, and people. Talent with certain know-how can help you create better quality products. But to make all that happen you need investors and business-savvy individuals who can open the doors you need to succeed in a competitive consumer space of other tech companies - your opponents who you meet over beers at conferences and in courtroom disputes over patent infringement.

Through a new and profound way of pairing a board game with an app on your phone, the initial barrier of getting past a complex set of rules is replaced by a progressive approach that teaches you the game through a simple first start-up story. Then it grows more and more complex over the course of multiple play sessions towards transforming you into becoming a massive tech giant in the end.

The app will also be used to communicate the narrative through audio storytelling, to communicate every mechanic’s tie-in to the theme and context, to manage gaming sessions in this new narrative format, where you can save your progress between play sessions, and to be a rules learning or reminder companion, to get you quickly back into the game, if you have had a break from it.

—description from the designer
categories: Economic, Industry / Manufacturing, Video Game Theme
mechanics: Dice Rolling, End Game Bonuses, Events, Hand Management, Legacy Game, Modular Board, Narrative Choice / Paragraph, Role Playing, Rondel, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation, Storytelling, Worker Placement

name: らくがき教科書 (Rakugaki Kyokasho)
description:
This is two games in one package; らくがき教科書 (Rakugaki Kyokasho) and よせがき教科書 (Yosegaki Kyokasho). Rakugaki means graffiti, Kyokasho is a textbook for children. The second game Yosegaki Kyokasho means Write Jointly Textbook.

The game is from Japan and is home-made. Packaged in a large pencil case, the components include large plastic sleeves with paper inside, wipeable marker pens, and a variety of small cut-outs of portraits and images of various kinds. These might be from famous Western artworks, such as the Mona Lisa or Venus, or famous people such as Beethoven or Napoleon, or animals or objects. Likewise there are popular Japanese characters such as writers, samurai or politicians (including Admiral Perry!), or figures from ukiyo-e scrolls.

The idea of the game is to mimic writing graffiti in your school textbooks. Players put the cut-outs inside the wallets, backed with the white paper. They then use the markers to write their jokes and graffiti on the outside of the wallet, as if writing on the schoolbook. Then players compare their jokes and the funniest is given points. Most points wins.

The designer says "Let's draw a bikini on Sakamoto Ryōma!" (famous samuari and democrat).

The alternate game has players taking turns to choose a theme, such as 'alternate hairstyles', and players draw images to that theme in the same way. This is for players who are not used to making up rude jokes.
user summary

name: Erzähl mir was vom Bauernhof
description: There's always something going on at the farm: cows, horses, pigs, rabbits and chickens run around happily and the tractor chugs across the yard. There is a lot to discover and name, which expands vocabulary and trains perception. The cute figures invite free play and the first rule game. Who finds the right place for his animal?

name: Schweizer Trachten-Spiel
description: The players move by dice over a circuit to collect cards with Swiss costumes cards. The goal is to get sets of 4 cards from as many neighboring cantons as possible to get many extra points. Event cards and fields that lead to card loss are also present. The game ends when all costume cards have been distributed. The player with the most valuable sets wins.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Track Movement

name: La Cible
description:
Inspired by a French television show. The game is composed of series of questions of increasing difficulty: "the first round", "the definitions", "the continuation", "the auctions" and "the final".

No answers are provided in the game.

name: Recon Rescue
description:
A special forces recon unit was a on secret mission when their helicopter crashed in the middle of the Vietnam jungle. The unit survived but not the pilot. With the mission scrubbed you have to make to back to the extraction zone and back to safety before the enemy tracks you down and captures you.

Your unit is trying to get to the extraction zone and they are being tracked by the enemy. Each turn your unit and the enemy randomly draw a number of colored d6 in specific order and place them on the player and enemy cards. Depending on the color of the die drawn, will determine any extra bonuses you or the enemy receive. Your squad must defeat the enemies dice to move to the next jungle terrain card. Each move you make can add or delete to your supplies "dice". It is a race to see who can get to the extraction zone first. If the enemy reaches the EZ first, your unit is captured. If the unit reaches the EZ first, you win. Your unit has special abilities that can be used one per game so be careful when using them.

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Dice, Print & Play, Vietnam War
mechanics: Action/Event, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Höllfahren
description:
The board was used for moving pieces while the players played cards. Depending on where you landed, different rules applied. For example, you had to be quiet or address someone in a specific way. If you failed to follow the rules, you moved a step closer to the centre, where people were being cooked in a pot. If you ended up there, you lost. The last player left was the winner and took all the money.

—user summary

name: Quadragon
description:
Quadragon is a card-driven strategy game in which players build an army of dragons and dragon-riding wizards in order to steal their opponent's treasure and protect their own.

Each card in Quadragon uses both sides of the card, and both sides are split in two, meaning that each card can be used in 4 different ways. One side contains a dragon and treasure, the other a wizard and spell. Dragons are used to attack your opponent's treasure and defend your own. Treasure is used to pay for wizards. Wizards can also steal treasure directly, or ride similarly-colored dragons for even more points. Spells can be cast by wizards to directly manipulate the battlefield, for example rotating or flipping cards, or scoring points. Each side of a card can only be used if the text is facing you, and all cards rotate after use. For example after attacking with a dragon it rotates to reveal its treasure, which makes it vulnerable to attack.

It is always a thrill to chain together a sequence of spells to flip and rotate cards, culminating in a massive points-scoring attack. The first player to reach 50 points wins.

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Fantasy, Mythology, Print & Play

name: Quad Play: [4]Deck
description:
A non-traditional playing card deck based on The Quad Play game system.

Includes 40 cards. No fixed suits. Card are arranged in two dimensions and divided in two sides, so that suits can be set dynamically. Cards have positive, negative or zero value. The deck balance is 0.

The basic game ("Draw" or "Dr[4]w") rules:
Each card (quad) has 4 pieces (qarts) in one colour (dark or light). These ones define the quad's cost in pts. Dark (purple) qarts have non-negative costs and vice-versa. Center purple qart gives 4 pts as all four hearts intersect each other here. Triangular qart so gives 2 pts and outer one (leaf) means 0. For example, The Good Sign (a quad with 4 purple qarts in shape of full heart) costs 8 pts in total. Players (2 by default) pick 4 quads in a turn. The summary quads' cost in each hand multiplies by 10 (multiplier from 4 to 40). Other number quads to pick is possible (with an appropriate multiplier). The number of turns is conventional (1 by default). The leader in pts wins.
Actually, many traditional card games can also be played with the Quad Deck. The new game logic brings a new experience into a regular game-play.

[4] The Good Sign is first of all... [4]

—user summary

name: Logistix
description:
Logistix is about combining logistics and logic. In a large container terminal, as the leader of a forklift crew, you have to make sure that the right containers get onto your ship. Each ship must be loaded according to a certain loading plan and following certain rules, so that the unloading of the cargo at the destination port runs efficiently. As if that wasn't enough, the shipping company has given you special assignments for loading. The player who manages, with skill and a good portion of brainpower, to get into position for the right containers, load them onto the ship according to the rules and fulfil the shipping company's orders, collects the most points and wins the game.

In each round of Logistix you will go through two phases. In the first, each of you bids on the slots that contain your desired containers. You will have to use a lot of skill, maybe even bluffing, to get the right containers. Once you've got the containers, you'll have to solve the loading puzzle on your ship, keeping in mind the shipping company's assignments.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Contracts, Pattern Building, Set Collection

name: Math Batt: Mathematical Battle
description:
Math-Batt (Mathematical Battle) is a card game that teaches times tables to children in an explosion of excitement, bold colours, and adorable cartoon characters. Get the numbers on your side and win the war of multiplication! The fun starts with two or more players. The deck contains 90 cards, divided evenly. On each card you'll find one multiplication equation. To "battle" each player reveals the top card of their stack. The player with the highest equation result wins. For instance, 2 x 2 = 4 defeats 2 x 1 = 2. The winner takes all the cards played in the round. Sometimes battles result in a "draw" where players end up with the same number. When this happens the two must duel in a "war". Players take two cards from their hand, placing one face down and the next face up. Whoever has the higher face-up card wins the war, and takes the other players' pair of cards. Players who run out of cards during the war immediately lose. The game continues until only one player emerges victorious with all 90 cards!

—description from the publisher

name: Winter War 1939: A Solo Game
description:
Winter War 1939: A Solo Game

A solo game where you command a platoon of Finnish infantry trying to stop waves of Russian attackers.
The Russians will still keep on coming until they eventually win.
The object of the game is to see how many waves of attackers you stop.

A simple to play game with lots of variety to keep the game different each time you play.

Turn Sequence:
1- Activate Russian troops
2- Activate Finnish troops
3- Roll for random events

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Das Zehnkampfspiel
description:
The players roll a die and move around the game board while competing in the 10 decathlon disciplines. They may accept the result of the space they land on or choose to roll again to achive a better result, thereby risking a fail by overshooting the last space of this discipline. If this is the case they have to complete this discipline in another trip around the board. On some spaces events hinder or benefit the players.

When the first player completes all 10 disciplines the game ends and the player who scored the most points wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Push Your Luck, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Die Posträuber
description:
The players, as the police, try to catch the main train robber, which is secretly determined by the robber-players and find the bag of loot by moving policemen around the game map and collecting hints. Movement is determined by a die.

The players form two teams: the police and the robbers. Any player may move any figure of hie own team. The robber team decides in secret which robber is the main culprit and which bag contains the loot. From this information they create a secret password from the main feature of the main culprit and the letter of the bag with the loot, for example Moon Boot (Monocle + B 001). The card with the number of the loot bag is removed from the stack and the stach is placed front down on it's space on the game board. The robbers and the bags (front down) are placed on the railway bridge and the police officers at police headquarters.

The robbers try to reach a hideaway (circular blue spaces), which can't be entered by a policeman. If a robber reaches a hideaway the player takes a bag from the bridge and places it inside the hideaway. The police have half an hour to find the main culprit and the bag with the loot. They try to reach the railway bridge while there are still some robbers and bags.

If a policeman gets to the railway bridge, he may turn over all the bags still there and takes all robbers still at at bridge to the prison to interrogate them.

If a figure gets on an orange space, the player takes the upper card from the stack and follows the instructions printed there, depending if he is a policeman or a robber. Some cards contain information for the police about empty bags.

The policemen take robbers into prison to interrogate them, if they land on a space occupied by a robber. During the first interrogation the robber has to tell the password. In further interrogations the police asks about the features of the main culprit (main feature, clothes, tie, ...). The robber has to answer truthfully wit "yes" or "no". Additionally the policeman may turn over any bag and ask, if this bag contains the loot.

The police wins, if they discover who is the main culprit and which bag contains the money inside half an hour. If not, the robbers win. The robbers win also if all get into hideaways, where they are safe from the police.
mechanics: Deduction, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: Spieleverlag Dr. Lindenberg, Verlag Schmidt Zwiebeltürme

name: Art Gallery
description:
In this game, each player assumes the role of an artist in the disputed world of galleries. Each player has one special skill from the character and must use them wisely throughout the game.

Each turn, one of the players will be the Maecenas and make a request. Each artist must choose one card in hand that best fits the Maecenas demand, the closer you get to it, the more points you get.

For the production of Art Gallery, the game designer Igor Colares invited dozens of people, among them children, adults, professional illustrators and amateurs. For each one, Igor asked for an art and said a feeling and an element. The artists then created based on that request. What we have as a result is an incredible variation of styles and a fun walk through the subjectivity of each person.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Judge, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: The Jester and the Minstrel (fan expansion for Carcassonne)
description:
It’s fair time in the region of Carcassonne! Travelling minstrels, jesters, jugglers, musicians and magicians gather together to provide fun and festivities for the peasants. News of the fair is spread far and wide, with some of the entertainers travelling the nearby countryside to announce the fair’s whereabouts. Some of these travelling showmen perform song and dance for their onlookers; others provide a bit of tom foolery and distract peasants from their duties.
Expands the Catapult with two new followers: the jester and the minstrel.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Medieval

name: Uphill
description:
Uphill is set in Discrimi Nation, where he inhabitants fight an intense battle, in which the wind favors the Nobles in power, while the peasants are desperately trying to climb the social ladder.

Each player gets warriors at random.

The peasantry hands over its strongest warriors to the nobility, while in turn the nobility passes its weakest warriors to the peasantry. Sounds fair? Depends on who you ask.

After that, based on how strong their army is, each player has to guess how many battles they are going to win.
Then the war begins: The King/Queen starts the game with placing a card on the table. Other players has to play a card with the same color. The stronger warrior hits the weaker (higher number hits the smaller one). The round is won by the player who played the highest card in the given color.

Based on the number of battles won, and how close were your guesses, power is redistributed, and ranks get swapped. You win some, you lose some.

And a new battle begins…

The player who can hold his/her Royal title 3 times in a row, wins the game.

name: Guntia: schnick's dir !!!
description:
In the game Guntia, you move your piece by rolling the dice on a map through the district of Günzburg to occupy free communities. You succeed in occupying a municipality if you win an extended Rock Paper Siccors (+2 more gestures) against your fellow players. Once a municipality is occupied, it may no longer be entered by other players, with the exception of the two municipalities in the centre. If a player has conquered 10 communities, or if a player cannot move for two rounds, the game is over. Points are awarded for occupied municipalities, as well as castles or coats of arms in the municipal area.

—user summary

name: 民の見えざる手 (Invisible Hands)
description:
民の見えざる手 (Invisible Hands) is a trick-taking card game from Japan.

The first king was a hero of the country and a man of great faith, but he died mad because he could not accept the overflowing voice of the people. The third king devoted all his energies to the development of the country and set up many enterprises, but the unprecedented heavy taxation caused the people to protest. The fourth king reduced taxes for the benefit of the people, but he failed to produce any results and was ridiculed as an ornament king. The fifth king finally became resentful, and instead of listening to the people, he brought great prosperity to the country by his own means, but he was called a tyrant by the people with whom he colluded, and was forced to leave his throne.

And the next king is about to be chosen from the candidates.
What do the people want from their next king?
Will they be able to live up to their hopes and show what it takes to be king?

This is a confrontational, unusual trick-taking game where you have to guess your own subject while trying to sabotage your rival's subject. It's a trick-taking game unlike anything you've seen before.
The game can be played by 3 or 4 players and there are also rules for 2 players.
publisher's summary

name: Tank Throwdown
description:
Tank Throwdown is a game of fierce tactical armored combat played with cards on any available surface. Customize the play area and compete to be the last one standing leaving your friend's tanks in smoking ruins. Play with up to 3 players using one deck or combine multiple decks so everyone can play!

Tank Throwdown plays similarly to a tabletop miniatures game but everything you need to play is in a single deck. Players use one card to represent their tank. Gameplay is handled by manipulating a small deck of action and response cards. Terrain and bonuses add variety to the play space. Games last from 5-20 minutes and can be set up almost anywhere there is a flat surface.

—description from the designer

name: Yoru: The card game
description:
Yoru is a chaotic and quick party card game. Players battle fiercely to get the eternal scrolls and win the match. In the game there are 5 ninja clans that hold the scrolls. Each clan has unique cards with different powers. Use the cards wisely and don't forget if you run out of cards, you lose the game.

At the beginning, all players receive 1 objective card at the beginning of the game. The player's objective card cannot remain in his hand, and must be turned over until the victory condition is reached. Then the main deck is shuffled and all players are dealt 5 cards. An objective card is face up. The player who has the most black pieces of clothing begins.

Players lose if they have no cards in their hand, or if they have more than 15 cards in their hand. The player wins if he has all the scrolls of the symbols on his objective card.

name: Tribu de Sinvergüenzas: Sigamos Pecando
description:
New cards that will allow you to continue enjoying these gray times.

You don't need the first version to play this new edition of Tribe of Scoundrels.

Leave your shame at home.

Tribu de Sinvergüenzas: Sigamos Pecando is a drinking game in which you will face three types of challenges: Indictment, Social Defiance, and WTF Questions.

If you dare, you must accuse others, respond with truth, or share the challenge.

At game's end, the player with the most points is expelled from the tribe, while the player with the fewest is named Head of the Scoundrel Tribe and winner of this game.

–description from the publisher (translated)
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Tierdetektiv
description:
Content: Inflatable Globe, 68 animal clue cards, hourglass, 1 die
The players roll the die and receive a clue to an animal from a clue card. A fellow player reads out the clue. Depending on the agreed level, the fellow player gives all or fewer clues.
The active player must now find the animal on the inflated globe within a given period of time in order to receive the clue card. The first player to collect 10 clue cards or one clue card from each of the 6 different colours (continents) wins the game.

name: Kult Spiel: deutschsprachige Literatur
description:
The players move their pieces across a playing field towards the goal by correctly answering questions about German-language literature. Each player can choose from 4 question cards, from the back of which he or she can already draw conclusions about the possible question. The player chooses a question card.

Then there are 4 possibilities: a) answer the question correctly with the announcement "Cult!" without any indication of the possible answers and move 3 spaces or b) first listen to the question and then answer correctly without any indication of the possible answers and move 2 spaces or c) listen to the question and the possible answers and answer correctly and move 1 space or d) answer the question incorrectly and stop.

The player who reaches the target field first wins.

—user summary

name: Commerciale-City-Play
description:
A Monopoly-like game in which players acquires shops, experiences events and answers quiz questions (16 picture cards) about famous buildings. The game does without the increases in value from houses and hotels.

—user summary
mechanics: Income, Loans, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Battle Cattle: Quest for the Holy Pail
description:
64 page expansion book that requires Battle Cattle second edition to play.

This Battle Cattle: second edition miniatures rules expansion book will give you the ability to play Battle Cattle in a world of swords and sorcery. Not only will the role of Battle Cattle in medieval times be explained, but you will have weapons, armor, accessories and modifications applicable to the time period. Add to this the element of moo-gic items and spells, and Battle Cattle becomes a whole new game.

—description from the back of the book
categories: Animals, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame

name: 宝石泥棒の予告状 (Houseki Dorobou no Yokokujou)
description:
宝石泥棒の予告状 (Houseki Dorobou no Yokokujou) is a game from Japan, meaning something like 'The Jewel Thief's Letter of Warning'. Originally produced in 2007, it was re-issued at the Tokyo Game Market in 2015.

This a trick-taking game but players don't have to -and may not want to- follow the colour (suit) lead. The cards show one, two or three colours each, and a player will receive a penalty chip for any color on their card which does follow the colour led.

The 40 card deck shows various aristocrats with their jewellery. The cards are ranked by number, and the 10 card is also a zero. Cards also show types of jewels in different clusters. The players are jewel thieves, trying to force their opponents into releasing valuable loot.

The designer says the unique scoring system can help a player overcome a bad hand.
user summary

name: Mineral Exploration
description:
It is your responsibility to find new mineral deposits. This job requires that you be alert with all your senses, that you use the latest technology and that you make good decisions.
Make sure they are economically, socially and environmentally viable!

In Mining Exploration your mission is to explore the terrain using your exploration cards. Each terrain must be explored with an appropriate action to earn its points. The player with the highest score at the end of the deck will win the game. The standard version of the game is recommended for people 10 years and older. For players with more experience, it has a section with extensions to the rules which will add more options to the games and an advanced version of the game.
Card game designed for the Explorations Corporate Management of CODELCO (National Copper Corporation of Chile). It was distributed to children in schools in the company influence territory. The objective is to teach the work of mining exploration and basic concepts of geology and mining.

—description from the designer

name: Hungry Cells
description:
Hungry Cells
Cells are the basic unit of life and of course, they have a lot of work to do! They are responsible for living beings to grow, breathe, walk, think and dream ... For this they need a large amount of energy and nutrients. In Hungry Cells you will know these nutrients and you will feed your favorite cell!
In Hungry Cells the players adopt the role of a cell, they must acquire the 6 nutrients that a cell needs to survive, the first cell to get them wins the game, but be careful! One cell may rob another of the nutrient already close to it.
Designed to teach the chemistry of food. It was the centerpiece of the annual booklet of the Science Week activities 2011, conducted by the EXPLORA CONICYT program (National Commission for Scientific and Technological Research) of the Ministry of Education of the Government of Chile. Hungry Cells was distributed along with the newspaper “La Tercera” throughout the country. Players had to craft the game with the central pages of the booklet.

—description from the designer

name: Karukinka
description:
Strange signs appear in the forest. Snow and frost show up earlier than expected. Why is summer coming to an end so soon? Venture out to investigate what is happening in the Karukinka Forest Boilers while escaping fearsome predators and saving resources to survive the harsh winter ahead.

In Karukinka, players take on the role of one of the squirrels in the Karukinka Forest. They must go through a first phase of the game, the warm phase, looking for seeds that allow them both to save and to acquire equipment, while facing predators. Then in the second phase of the game, the cold phase, they must face both the predators and the Winter Wraiths with the equipment they acquired and the savings they have collected. The game ends when the Winter Wraiths are defeated and the Boilers in the forest are reignited.

Karukinka was designed for the Financial Education Department of the Social Investment and Solidarity Fund (FOSIS) of the Ministry of Social Development of the Government of Chile. Its use was initially implemented in schools in five regions throughout Chile. Within the framework of a campaign to strengthen the value of savings in 14-15 years aged children. The game is widely appreciated by teachers and students. There have also been tournaments at the national level.

Karukinka mean “our land” in Selknam language, one of the indigenous people of Chile.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Grid Movement, Pick-up and Deliver, Selection Order Bid

name: 即売会! (Sokubaikai!)
description:
即売会! (Sokubaikai!) is a co-operative card game from Japan. It's a two-day spot sale, and the players want to clean up and grab all those bargains. The goal is to clear all their hands of all cards before the game ends. If any player is left holding a card at the end of the game, they all lose.

The game has a deck of 48 cards numbered 1-48. The cards are in sections each with their own theme, 1-9 (Kitakuba), 10-19 (butterflies), 20-29 (eyeglasses), 30-39 (yokai), 40-48 (fanzines).

The deck is shuffled and seven cards are dealt out face-down to each player. Players sort their hand and then choose a hand card, placing it face-down. Once everyone has chosen, they reveal their card, and the lowest card is placed first in the centre (onto an imaginary zero), and then the next card and so on (similar to Take 5. Cards are played into a pile, and lower cards are hidden and not to be examined later.

Then each player draws a card so their hand is back to seven, and play continues in the same way.

At any point, even at the start, a player can call for a trade, and all players pass a card to the left. Successive trades can be made in the same round, but only six trades are allowed in the whole game. A marker is moved along a track on the rear of the game box to count the trades.

Discussion is allowed in the game, but is limited. Players cannot say or imply a specific numbered card, but can talk in general about their cards. For example, 'I have two 20s', or 'I have zero Kitakuba'. In this way, players can work out which cards would be good to trade or keep in hand.

If a player cannot play a card to the pile legally, the first day of sales ends and the pile is set to one side. Play continues for a second day, starting at zero again. If a player cannot play legally again, day two ends and the players all lose.

If the players succeed in clearing their entire hands before day two ends, they all win.

(Note: this game was published in Japan in 2016, before The Mind in 2018).
user summary
mechanics: Communication Limits, Cooperative Game, Hand Management, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Rommel's Best!
description:
This is a variant of 「Guderian's Best.ver3.0」

Solitaire tank simulation board game.
I aim at surviving while it being the fight car head of the tank corps under the Erwin Rommel conduct as for you during a period from 1941 through 1943, and fighting against the military unit of the British military.
"The command of the air" and "temperature" added the element of "the sandstorm" to the game system newly after having followed 「Guderian’s Best」 of Mr. Nigel Hodge.

name: Fulda liebenswert-lebenswert ...spielend kennenlernen
description:
The players roll the die and move their game piece along a given path through the German municipality of Fulda. They can collect victory points (5, 10, 15 or 20) at specially marked squares. To reach these fields, you may also move backwards. The first player to reach the target field with at least 500 victory points wins.

—user summary
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Gatekeeper
description:
Gatekeeper is an intense 2-player cardgame that has you pitched against an opponent in a duel. In four locations you will position witches out of your hand and attempt to take control in small and larger scale confrontations, with the mysterious Gatekeeper playing a merciless referee using some unique dynamic mechanics.

When positioning a witch of a specific element at a location, columns are formed. A new witch will compare her spellpower with that of the opposing witch, with the higher value "dazzling" the weaker party. In dazzled state, witches are vulnerable for the vicious Gatekeeper that is now activated by the Gatekeeper value on the last played witch, moving X-number of locations in a set cycle movement. In the location she lands in, she will check if a dazzled witch is present and eliminate her from the contest.

Next, she will activate a rondel and move a marker to the next position, activating the next Element Gate in line.
By activating the gate she awakens all the witches of this element present at the location, triggering a larger scale confrontation, with the player holding majority inflicting damage equal to the number of withes they have present. The defending player can however fend off part of the attack with opposing witches.

Each witch also cast 1 of 10 unique special spells, each manipulating parts of the duel in devious ways. This additional layer creates tough decisions in an already challenging duel of wits.

Will you control the Astral plane by lowering the mana level of your opponent to "0"?

—description from the publisher

name: Super Kontakt
description:
The game aims to illustrate the performance characteristics of a 20th century Siemens "EMS" programmed telephone. The players are to move their 6 game pieces in turn to target fields by rolling the dice. Before the sixth playing piece may enter a target field, all so-called "contact chips" must be used up. In order to gain certain advantages in the course of the game, the players must collect cards with features of the telephone on predefined fields. These are, for example, the right to enter a target field, to hand over more contact chips, to enter occupied fields, etc.
The first player to hand in all contact chips and move their 6th piece to a target field wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Track Movement

name: Kung-Fu
description:
Kung-Fu is played on a 10*9 field. Each player has 3 pieces, 1 great master (Shihan) and 2 fighters (Bujin), which he places on his baseline.

Players move their pieces alternately and have to allocate 2 movement points to their pieces. On squares that the pieces leave, they leave obstacle stones (Ate, 30 pieces). These can be jumped over if the square behind them is free. 3 special obstacle stones (Geri) prevent them from being jumped over.
