There are 3 ways to win the battle, a) move your own Shihan to the opponent's baseline or b) capture the opponent's Shihan or c) capture the opponent's Bujin and immobilise the opponent's Shihan. Any other result is considered a stalemate.

—user summary
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Square Grid, Static Capture

name: Staatsmann
description:
The players have to start from point zero after a war in order to get their country's economy going again.

To do this, they can disband existing armies (but lose power) in order to improve education, nutrition, raw material supply and consumer goods industries. Negotiations with the opposing countries, non-aggression pacts and lots of events as well as a variety of dice results control the course of the game.

The balance of power represented by armies (heavy metal chips) and thus decision-making powers is measured on a weight scale.

Two of the participating countries are so-called crisis countries, which have even worse starting conditions. They can also be played as non-player countries.

The player who leads his country to prosperity in the most economic sectors wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Contracts, Dice Rolling, Events, Income, Simulation

name: Age of Musket: Shako and Musket 1854-1856 – Rules for scaled battles of the Crimean War
description:
These rules are part of a series that cover the era of the Musket (1690's - mid 19th century).
The rules of Shako and Musket 1854-1856 are designed to capture the flavour of this specific war with the subtle changes and nuances.
They are designer to be easy to use, fast flowing and capable of covering small and large games.

Sequence of play:
1- Declare Charges
2- Charge response check
3- Charge reaction movements
4- Melee resolution
5- Breakthrough check (for charging units)
6- Breakthrough follow-up (resolve new melees)
7- Breakthrough results per 6
8- Other movement
9- Other fire
10- Morale check
11- Morale reaction (retire, retreat, rout, follow-up)

Miniatures: 2mm to 25mm
Players will need a tape measure, D6, pen and paper

– extract from rulebook

name: Paradise-Opoly
description:
Paradise-Opoly is a nostalgic and detailed memoir of the small mountain town of Paradise, CA that was devastated by wildfire in 2018. The games base mode uses classic monopoly mechanics and is completely redesigned and re-themed around Paradise culture, history and community. The process of whittling down what would be represented from the town involved hundreds of community members suggesting and voting online what should be included. The result is a rich and well-rounded portrayal of our little town. My main purpose in the design of the game was for it to really give someone that feeling of home when they play it, whether you are from there or not. Nearly every person who was in Paradise that day lost everything. Not only their homes, pets and even family members, but they lost their community. The town was completely changed forever in a matter of hours. My intent is to capture the spirit of Paradise that so many love, cherish and miss dearly.

I am not a game developer, by any means. I just had an idea, shortly after the fire, to create this game to commemorate the town. Since that idea I have learned many things and the idea has grown into a beautifully designed and well thought out game. I am currently in the middle of a Kickstarter campaign and fully expect to reach my funding goal so I can produce 3000 games. 100% of the net-profits from my company sales of the games and merchandise will be donated back to non-profits aimed at immediate rebuilding projects for lower income residents of Paradise. I intend to represent my town and help in any way I can.

The game features fun, vibrant and colorful artwork and design by Traci Van Wagoner and Kurt Keller of Imagine That! Design in New York. They have done an amazing job with conveying the detail and nuance I wanted in every illustration and design. All of the metal game miniatures are custom designed by the very talented 3D sculptor, Chad Hoverter, and represent somethng special and unique to Paradise. Even the old "houses and hotels" are now Miner's Tents and Log Cabins, one of the many references to the very prominent gold rush history of the area. All of the "Property" cards contain a short story or description about the landmark or place they contain. Included is a full color information booklet with extended versions of the stories. For some playing that weren't locals or for kids who may not know all the history of their town the game serves as a fun learning experience of the towns culture and beginnings.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Income, Loans, Lose a Turn, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Track Movement, Trading

name: You Decide: The Financial Education Game
description:
Your family has come together to plan their finances. You already know your current situation and what your financial goal is, but… How will you reach that goal? What will your strategy be?

In “You Decide” (Tú Decides) the players adopt the role of a family that seeks to fulfill its great financial goal, while worrying about the income, expenses, debts and contingencies of each month. Each family has an economic situation that must improve, for this they make financial planning decisions and each month they can choose which aspect of their family finances they give special care to. The family first to achieve its great financial goal wins the game.

This game was developed for the financial education department of the Solidarity and Social Investment Fund (FOSIS) of the Ministry of Social Development of the Government of Chile, to be used in training for heads of household in all regions of the country.
More than 4000 units have been distributed and it is in its third edition. Apart from head of household training, It has been distributed and applied to schools throughout Chile and has been successfully received by teachers and students. National tournaments have also been held.

—description from the publisher

name: Save Now
description:
Save now (original title "Ahorra es Cuando")

You are part of a group of friends. You all have different interests, but, in turn, you have something in common: you want to have fun, do activities and buy the things you want. To achieve your goals, you must earn money, save, and learn about yout rights. But be careful! You could find advertising or tempting offers that make you spend impulsively, going out of budget or buying things that you do not really need or that do not meet your expectations.

In Save Now you will assume the role of a young man or woman, seeking to achieve your savings goals. In each round of the game you must plan your activities and manage your budget, making decisions that allow you to earn money and save or spend it. Doing the things you love and meeting your savings goals will earn you victory points to win the game.

Save Now is a Financial Education game developed for the National Costumers Service of Chile (SERNAC), aimed at high school youth from all over Chile with the aim of encouraging savings and responsible consumption practices.

Through this material, young players will apply concepts such as planning and budgeting, managing their income based on one or more savings goals. In this way, the game allows to consolidate financial knowledge acquired in various training instances and to understand saving as a fundamental habit in the development of healthy consumption behaviors in the face of current market conditions.

—description from the designer

name: Das Weinstraßen Spiel
description:
This promotional game for the German Weinstrasse region is structured like Monopoly, but without the game element of investing in houses and hotels. Increases in value result from 6 share cards per business colour, each of which can be bought at a fixed price. Some of the event cards (profits and losses are possible) are directly related to all business colours.

—user summary
mechanics: Events, Income, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Obolus
description:
The players roll the number- and color-die and set a game token on the corresponding space of the game board. If the space is already occupied the player pays a coin into the cash bowl.

The game ends when a player sets a token onto the last free space of any color. This player wins the game and the contents of the cash bowl.

—user summary

name: Don't Be Stupid!
description:
You put the cards, hourglass and coins on the table. You then divide into teams of any size or type.

The starting player then draws a card and asks the question on the card to everyone. The first team to answer correctly wins the card and all braggin' rights associated with winning the card. BUT you can use whatever means to figure out the answer. Google it, Bing it (Is that still a thing?), Call a friend, etc. You can do anything to find the answer.

After answering the question for the team, it is now time for the individual team members to show their skills and win the debate round.

The individual winner (as decided by popular vote) of the debate round gets one of those shiny gold coins.

Play a few rounds and then announce the team winner and the overall individual winner.
OR...
You can just throw out the rules and play the game with your own house rules.

—description from the designer

name: Navy Battle Card Game
description:
A trick-taking card game with cards featuring photos of contemporary United States Navy aircraft, surface ships, and submarines.

The cards are marked with letters from A to Z and some of the cards are numbered as well (i.e. A1, A2, A3, A4). At the start of the game, each player is dealt seven cards. The goal is to capture the most Navy equipment by winning tricks. The highest card played wins the trick, with A being the highest and Z being the lowest. In addition, among the numbered cards with the same letter, the highest number wins (so B4 beats B2).

At the end of the game a player receives 10 points for each card having a number and 5 points for each card that only has a letter. A player can score a bonus 100 points during the game if the cards in the player's hand spell out N-A-V-Y, J-E-T, or S-H-I-P. The first player to reach 1000 points wins the game.

The contents include the rules folder, 54 cards, a score pad, and a small cardboard box-insert tray. The rules folder provides a description of each photo used on the cards.

—user summary
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Modern Warfare, Nautical

name: The Fifty Game
description:
Players take turns placing pegs on a 50-hole track. At the start of each game, Player A chooses a range of number provided at the top corner of the board. Player B then moves his peg by any number of holes inside the chosen range. Player A then does the same but starting from the position of Player B's peg. First to reach the 50th hole wins.

—user summary

name: The Warriors of Athena
description: The Warriors of Athena is a solo skirmish game set in the world of Greek mythology. The player creates a hero, recruits a warband to accompany and fight alongside them, and then sets out on quests given to them by the goddess Athena. It uses a variant of the Frostgrave rules set. It was featured in two issues of Wargames, Soldiers & Strategy magazine, and then later collected in Spellcaster # 6.
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: The Smiley Face Game
description:
Three games in one packaged in a wooden box.

1. The Smiley Face Game
Players roll dice and race through a 9x9 square grid collecting smiley face disks. The disks are placed at random with the exception of the triple smiley face which is placed at the last space (no. 81). Landing on a space occupied by another player pushes a piece back to the next available unoccupied space. Players collect smiley face disks if they land on a space occupied by a disk. If a smiley face is passed by all players, that disk is placed on the highest available number on the board. Landing on a smiley face disk gives another turn; landing on a double smiley face gives two extra turns. The game ends when a player lands with an exact roll on the last space (no. 81). The player with the most smiley faces at the end wins the game.

2. The Smiley Face Game with no dice
Setup is the same as the first game. Players do not move according to dice rolls but according to a chosen number between 1-5.

3. Odd Even Tag
The game board is a hexagonal ring formed by smaller hexagons. Players choose to play as even or odd. Player take turns rolling dice and the player counters are moved according to the number of dice rolled and if it's odd or even. The first player to tag the other wins.

—user summary

name: 45 Game and Factors Game
description:
Two games in a wooden box

1. Factors Game
The playing board is a grid of hexagons with number on each space. Players take turns throwing a dice and moving their markers to an adjacent space that is a multiple of the number on the dice. First to reach the finish wins.

2. 45 Game
The board is similar to the one used in the Factors Game except the numbers on each space are different. Players add the number shown on the dice to the number their markers are on. If the sum is a number which is adjacent to the space they're on, they can move to that new space. First to reach the top (45) is the winner.

—user summary

name: The War on the Ground: World War 2 Wargame Rules
description:
Experience the harsh realities of commanding your own force. When lives are on the line and victory is in the balance, there are no easy decisions.

War on the Ground is a game system for tabletop actions, designed to give a realistic and enjoyable game for 12mm/1:144 scale miniatures.
The game covers all aspects of WWII combat including infantry, armour, artillery and aerial encounters.

These rules also include a separate fast play reference sheet and five historical scenarios to get you started.

5 historical scenarios in Normandy 1944:

Barneville (18th June)
Operation Mitten (27th June)
Panzer Lehr counter attacks (11th July)
Running into some trouble (18th July)
The bridge at Flavigny (9th/10th September)


–description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: Looting Alien Ruins
description:
Each player commands a small team trying to loot a long abandoned alien city they must deal with each other and also any traps and creatures that may have been left behind by the previous inhabitants.

Ideal for multi player games with any scale of figures as long as they are individually based.

Turn Sequence:
1- Activate the player's forces
2- Roll for random events
3- Roll for the game clock

–description from the publisher

name: Command Decision: Volume 1
description:
12 Scenarios with maps and a variety of tactical options. Largely taken from actual actions across all periods but easily transferable to any period.

Scenarios:

Hazara 1888
Ohio 1758
Pyrenees 1813
Villers Bocage
St Crispins Day
Spotsylvania
Crete 1941
Kadesh
Tarakan 1942
Scottish Borders
India 1857
Spain 1809


–description from the publisher
categories: Age of Reason, American Civil War, Ancient, Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Post-Napoleonic, Wargame, World War II

name: Español
description:
"Learn Spanish as you play Berlitz español (sic), the continental word playing card game. The pleasant way to practice Spanish. Exciting, challenging, educational."

"Español is a game designed to give you a fundamental basis for learning the Spanish language. In addition to being educational, it is absorbing and entertaining for both teenagers and adults."

"The object of the game is to form sentences from the words printed on the cards. Points are scored for each card used. Sentences may be constructed with two or more cards."

The player with the highest score at the end of the game is the winner.
mechanics: Hand Management, Melding and Splaying, Sudden Death Ending

name: DragonCraft
description:
DragonCraft is a card game about the players playing Hero cards to acquire and hatch valuable Dragon Eggs. The first player to have three victory points provided by hatched dragons wins.

The heroes are usually spending their time in the inn, waiting for adventure. They wait until all four are present in the party - fighter, thief, mage and priest. These days there is a high demand for captured dragons so then they go to the dungeon and return with a captured dragon egg (well they do their best to choose an egg with a dragon inside but sometimes they pick the wrong one containing something worthless like a giant snake or an ostrych). This is the most noble and heroic way to acquire a dragon egg. Real heroes do it this way.

There are some players with less honor who take an easier approach. An approach that includes stealth and shady figures in cloaks. Those players may simply steal eggs from other players. (Actually this happens pretty often) You may say that this is not that heroic and noble but the result is the same and the dragon egg is as good as one that the heroes could get from a long and exhausting adventure.

The acquired egg still needs to hatch. If you have the right cards - two mages - you can hatch the egg. This is a very delicate process where the mages have to use their magic very carefully so that the creature inside the egg is not hurt. (but usually they just blast it with fireballs) Hatched dragons give victory points and the player who first has three wins.

—description from the designer

name: Mitozo
description:
Mitozo is an turn-based abstract strategy game with an oriental flavour, designed by Pablo Soto Cid.

It was designed as a pen and paper game for two players, but can be played with a regular square board and "white/black" pieces.

Players take turns to fill every position on the game grid, with only one rule: if the piece to be placed is going to contact the opponent, it also must contact a previous piece from the player.

The goal of the game is to make impossible for the rival to place any more pieces before the board is completely filled.

—description from the designer

name: Flip Tennis
description:
A game for 2 or 4 players where the game is played on a rectangular tennis court board. Players flip a disc in tiddly wink style over a net placed in the center of the board . If the disc falls into a specific circled area the player gains points. First player to reach 100 points is the winner.

Produced in Australia by the National Game Company and recorded in the Australian National Archives as being registered in 1903.

—user summary

name: BelloLudi: World War I – Skirmish Game 1914-1918
description:
This ruleset simulates battles in the period of 1914 to 1918, the years in which the worlds’ nation fought one of the greatest conflicts in human history, the Great War or First World War. The rules will work for skirmishes in this era, but also in conflicts shortly before and after as the Balkan Wars and the various conflicts of the Interbellum were largely fought with the same material and tactics. The first World war was a period of tremendous changes in equipment and tactics. These rules will give you the options of playing the first skirmishes of 1914, the trench warfare that dominated the middle of the war and the combined arms tactics that were developed at the end of the war.

Cards and special dice are available separately.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: BelloLudi: World War II – Skirmish Game 1939-1945
description:
This ruleset simulates battles in the period of 1939 to roughly 1945, the age in which the worlds’ nation fought the greatest conflict in human history, the Second World War. The rules will work for skirmishes in this era, but also in conflicts shortly before and after as the Spanish civil war and the Korean war were largely fought with the same material and tactics.

In an ideal battlefield situation the enemy was pinned in place or disorganised by the concentrated fire of infantry and artillery. Once this was accomplished, other units could deliver the coup de grace. Tactics were therefore based on teamwork between units, on fire and movement. Every unit would have its own specific task and if they executed their tasks in unison, success was often achieved. The aim in this game, is not to annihilate the enemy’s units to the last man, but to inflict enough damage that morale is reduced and the unit will become shaken or will run away in panic and consequently removed from the tabletop. By a clever combination of movement, shooting and dashing cavalry charges, this can be achieved. The tactics are based on teamwork. Not only within a group, but also between groups and as such, the whole army.

Your role will be that of a commander of a small group of soldiers. Should any disagreement arise concerning the rules, we suggest you roll a dice. The one who rolls the highest number has it right, for now.

So onwards, to glory!

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Korean War, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Rompan El Fuego
description:
Rompan El Fuego gives you all the Troop, AFV, and Gun Classifications you need to wargame the Spanish Civil War in conjunction with 1 man / vehicle = 1 platoon WW2 rules such as the popular Rapid Fire Fast Play Rules For WWII.

Also included are supplementary rules together with a handful of amendments which will bring some of the unique character of this conflict onto your tabletop.

There are also notes on weapons and tactics to be found within the main body of the text.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: フェイバリットマーケット (Favorite Market)
description:
フェイバリットマーケット (Favorite Market) is a card game from Japan, with players tweeting out their influence.

During a high school festival, students want their favourite food stalls to succeed. So they use their tweets and followers to promote themselves and their trends, through stealth marketing. Players can like tweets and retweet, and try to make the festival more exciting.

The players have a personal trend and combine this with a stall to create up to 20 different combinations. They each secretly support three of the stalls.

There is a deck of tweets (using the actual twitter accounts from the doujin circle and their friends), and retweet cards. By playing tweets, liking and retweeting, they can promote the stalls they support.

On a player's turn, they get to do any two actions from three (same action if they like):

Choose one of the three posts on the common timeline and 'Like' it to apply the card effect.

Refresh the timeline, which turns on new posts and removes old ones from the timeline.

'Retweet', which brings back to the timeline a post that was liked in the past, although its use is limited.

As they players perform the actions, their stock of customers goes down. The game ends when all the customers are gone.

The player who earns the most points wins the game by comparing the number of customers in their supporting shop, secretly decided at the beginning of the game, and finally adding up the bonuses for meeting special conditions.
user summary
mechanics: Action Points, Hidden Roles, Tile Placement

name: Stop Thief
description:
A Morton Thinking Cap game produced in the 1960s.

In Stop Thief one player is the police and the other players are robbers in a game of cat and mouse. Rolling a die to move or using the bus routes available the robbers roam the city to steal cash from the banks and post offices. The robbers try to avoid being captured by the policemen on the beat or the patrol car.

The police earn bonus cash by catching robbers red-handed after a theft and if a robber is gaoled four times they are eliminated from the game. The robbers stash their loot in hideouts until they can afford the fare to leave the country by train, ship or aeroplane.

The winner is the player with the most money at the end of the game which can be either the police in the city or one of the robbers who has successfully escaped abroad.

—user summary

name: 2020: Extension Pack +
description:
A game designed for those that wish to leave 2020 behind! Create your circle of friends to help you survive the financial hardships of 2020. Do whatever it takes to survive this year above the rest but remember: Problematic players lose their jobs, sponsorships, friends and sometimes even money.

Players gain survival points based on the cards that they play, and when a player has acquired fifteen survival points, the end of the game is triggered. At the end of that round, players count their money and the player with the most money wins.

With the 2020: Extension Pack +, players will encounter 52 exclusive social media cards that give players the a chance to look back and laugh at the monstrosity of 2020.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Income, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Pumpkin Killer Man
description:
A card game based on a simple turn by turn system, on your turn turning over cards to find villagers, to gain points, but if you draw Pumpkin Killer Man, you're dead! Try to save the people of Fallville, and get out alive. This game includes many different ways to play and extra rules to add mechanics to the base style of play.

—description from the designer

name: Forgotten Battles from France to Germany: January to April 1945
description:
This book contains 23 battle scenarios, covering the period of January to April 1945. It also includes special rules for each scenario.

New weapons, armour and infantry types can be applied to any set of rules. Including War on the Ground.

If you are under the impression that the last few months of the Second World War in Western Europe was a ‘walk in the park’, this book will prove otherwise!

Some of the hardest fighting took place from January to April 1945 and here you will find historical battles, which most will not have come across before.
The scenarios are testing and will be a challenge for all wargamers.

–description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Warhammer Age of Sigmar (Second Edition): Broken Realms – Be'lakor
description:
While the Mortal Realms rage under the fires of countless wars, one scorned figure looks to take advantage and further his unknowable agenda. Be'lakor, the Dark Master, whose schemes have had their twisted tendrils in many momentous events, begins to enact the final stages of his grand ambition. With the beleaguered Stormcast who followed Morathi into the Eightpoints making their retreat back across the Bloodwind Spoil, and the Seraphon beginning their own assault upon Archaon's realm, what could the first and greatest of the Daemon Princes have in store?

The third instalment in the Broken Realms series sees the hidden machinations of Be'lakor come to the fore as the Dark Master begins to take a more direct role in the Mortal Realms' events. The dire consequences will ripple across multiple factions, including an unforeseen alliance between Chaos and Death, the march of the Seraphon's Celestial Stampede, and the introduction of siege warfare to Warhammer Age of Sigmar.

Inside this 112-page hardback book, you'll find:


The chilling tale of Be'lakor's grand plan to usurp the Everchosen and take his place as the foremost champion of Chaos



Rules for the Legion of the First Prince, including an expanded warscroll for Be'lakor himself and updated battle traits, spells and artefacts for his Slaves to Darkness warband



Coalition of Death rules allowing you to play team-based games including 3 or more players, who may need to team up temporarily to take out a threatening foe while keeping an eye out for their so-called 'allies'



Six battleplans to help you recreate pivotal moments from the story, as well as Realms of Battle rules to represent the unique locations they were fought in



Rules to tie the battleplans into a narrative campaign depicting Be'lakor's assault upon the Mortal Realms



A bounty of warscrolls, warscroll battalions and unit updates for Kharadron Overlords, Fyreslayers, Stormcast Eternals, Disciples of Tzeentch, Nighthaunt, and Seraphon


—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Variable Player Powers

name: Escaping The Orcs: A Solo Game
description:
In Escaping The Orcs, you control a group of human slaves trying to escape from their Orcish oppressors.
The game is played over four scenarios as you escape and then search for a safe home while being pursued by angry Orcs.

Ideal for 28mm figures but any scale will do as long as they are individually based.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Sci-Fi Return: A Solo Game
description:
In Sci-Fi Return, you must enter a damaged space station and recover some information.
The station is in danger of falling apart and various dangerous creatures have escaped and are roaming the facility.

This is a sequel to Sci-Fi Escape but is a stand alone game you don't need anything else to play it.

Ideal for 28mm figures but you can use whatever comes to hand.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Goblin Trek 2: A Solo Game
description:
In Goblin Trek 2 you must bring your party of Goblins to safety while being pursued by Orcs through a hostile desert.

A solo game much like the original Goblin Trek but in this game the desert itself is hostile and the terrain areas while possibly home to hostile creatures are also the only shelter from the heat of the desert.

Easy to learn with enough variables to make each game a different experience.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Elfs vs Dwarfs: A Solo Game
description:
Elfs vs Dwarfs is a solo game in which you can play either the Dwarves or the Elves trying to hold out until relieved.

A simple and easy to play game with lots of random options to make each game different.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Czech Legion: A Solo Game
description:
The Czech Legion famously travelled all the way across Russia during the Russian Civil War
This game represent a small skirmish along the way.

A solo game where you command a small group of soldiers returning from a foraging mission with valuable supplies and being attacked by a force of bandits.

This will work in any scale as long as the figures are individually based.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Bagration 1944: A Solo Game
description:
Bagration 1944 is a solo game where you command a Russian infantry platoon trying to clear out some German forces left behind after your forces rapid advance.

Simple to play.
Will work in any scale as long as the figures are individually based, lots of options to keep the game varied each time it is played.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: After Hastings: A Solo Game
description:
After Hastings is a solo game in which you have to get a small party of Anglo-Danes to safety in the aftermath of the Battle of Hastings, while being pursued by the victorious Norman forces.

Simple to learn and play requires individually based figures ideally 28mm but any side will do.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Vikings: A Solo Game
description:
Vikings is a solo game where you command a group of Vikings cut off and trying to make it to safety while being pursued by lots of angry Anglo Saxons.

A simple game to learn and play but should be lots of fun with plenty of variable factors to make each game different.

Requires individually based figures ideally 28mm but any scale will do.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Dwarfs Last Stand: A Solo Game
description:
Dwarfs Last Stand is a solo game you command a small force of Dwarfs attacked by hordes of orcs who can't win.
It is simply a matter of how long you can hold out for.

Easy to learn rules for a fun evenings gaming.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Dwarven Beer: A Solo Game
description:
Dwarven Beer is a solo game in which you have to transport a wagon full of beer across an area infested with goblins who also want the beer.

You command a small group of Dwarfs plus the beer wagon the goblins are controlled by the rules.

The game has plenty of random factors to keep it different every time you play, easy to learn and fun to play.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Market Trend
description:
Market Trend is a market game from Japan, with players working as jewellers. The price of the different gemstones varies according to demand; when players put out new designs and clusters, prices go up, and fall for the gems out of popularity. Players aim to be the richest jeweller by the end of four rounds.

The game has 120 gem cards for different types, from 10 diamonds to 24 jet. The deck is varied for the number of players.

Once the deck is prepared and shuffled, players are dealt 8 hand cards. (If the deck is exhausted leter, discards are shuffled over).

Players then select one card to keep as stock, placing it face-down in front of them, and pass their hand to their neighbour (alternating each round). Then players can sell gems or sets of gems from their hand and make cash.

The value of what they sell is determined by a scoring plan, and alters each round. At the end of the game, there is a final bonus too.

Players can now move the prices of the gem types up or down, according to what they did and did not sell. After this, players are dealt back to 8 cards (or as best can be done), and the game continues.

At the end of the game, the stock cards the players have been collecting are scored for a final bonus. After this, most cash wins.

The distribution of the gem cards matters, and players try to keep in mind which gems they have seen and which have been sold. Understanding which are going to be rarer by the end of the game is a key strategy.
user summary

name: Golf Shot Game
description:
Players take turns rolling three special six-sided dice with three golf balls, "hook", "slice", and "trap". Each player start with three coins. Each dice roll determines what happens to the coins, either pass a coin to the left (hook), pass a coin to the right (slice), put a coin in the center (trap), or keep the coin (golf ball). Game ends when only one player is left with coins, and he/she wins the coins in the center.

—user summary

name: Tower of Dice
description:
Tower of Dice is a fast-paced dice rolling dexterity game. The goal is to create a tower of dice faster than your opponent(s) to win the game.

Currently Tower of Dice is a rule set you can download and play yourself at home with 2-6 opponents. You will need a lot of dice...A LOT of dice...depending on the number of players, but two players should get by with 30-40 six-sided dice.

With multiple play modes from basic (stacking dice of like-numbered rolls) to more advanced (using basic math to calculate what your next dice roll should be) the game can satisfy almost any age group for a quick and fun play.

—description from the designer

name: War Between The Stars
description:
The exploration of space was carried out primarily by large corporations which soon found out that valuable resources were few and far between and soon they were in conflict over the few good systems.
After some years things settled down leaving a number of what had become in effect nations looking greedily at each other’s possessions.
The year is 2264 and border skirmishes are common, the discovery of a string of new valuable systems would set off a war that would destroy many of these new nations between the stars.
This war was known as the War of Expansion.

War Between The Stars is a game of starship combat.
It uses a couple of ships or play larger games with whole fleets, lots of ship designs to use as well as a design system to create your own.
There are also a few sample scenarios to get you started and as an introduction to the War of Expansion.

The rule are simple and easy to learn but the use of special features allows for the construction of unique fleets that each has its own advantages.

Sequence of Play:

Starting with whoever has the most ships, the players move alternate ships until all ships have been moved.
Conduct firing, all of which is considered to be simultaneous.
All ships may try to repair damage then
start the next move


—description from the rulebook
categories: Aviation / Flight, Book, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: War Between The Stars: Carriers
description:
War Between The Stars: Carriers is a supplement for War Between The Stars that introduces the use of Carriers and Fighters into the game.

This is not a stand alone game you will need a copy of War Between The Stars to use it.

Includes some sample ships and a scenario

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: I Need More Trees!
description:
A set of rules for fighting the French and Indian Wars ideally using 28mm figures but other scales will work as long as the figures are individually based.

Designed to represent the smaller encounters that took place in the forest using maybe 80-120 figures/side though larger multi player games would also work.

Easy to learn and play these rules should keep you on your toes especially when there are Indians hiding in the forest and you don't know where or how many.

Turn Sequence:

Randomly determine who moves first for the turn
Alternately activate units until all activation points have been used
Test morale for all units that have poor morale
categories: American Indian Wars, Book, Miniatures, Wargame

name: Spacefighters: War in the Belt
description:
As the Earth ran out of resources humanity became more and more dependent on the huge amount of resources available in the asteroid belt. The mining of these was left to a number of corporations that soon started fighting over the most valuable asteroids.
The game represents these encounters between groups of spacefighters played on a hex grid using either counters or model ships normally 2-3 ships/player but larger games are possible and using multiple players will help to model the chaotic nature of these combats.

A set of rules for fighter combat in the asteroid belt.
Needs a hex grid to play and some 10 and 6 sided dice.
You could use counters or models to represent the ships .

The ships are armed with cannons and missiles with limited ammunition so games will come to a natural end rather than continuing until all of one side is destroyed.

Some sample ships are to start with but you can easily design your own.

Turn Sequence:

Roll to recover control
Set ship speed unless out of control
Choose to fly evasive or normal
If not evasive or out of control can roll to repair damage
Move out of controlships
Move evasive ships
Move all other ships
Missiles take effect
Firing with cannons
Firing with missiles


–description from the rulebook
categories: Aviation / Flight, Book, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Subway Network
description:
Subway Network is a game from Japan. Players are constructing rail networks in Tokyo or Osaka. By building stations, operating typical businesses on the stations, such as convenience stores, and increasing passengers, players score points to win.

The game has a board on which track cards are placed. Each card has three rail lines in different patterns and hence 6 points of entry/exit. Each card also has two stations, of municipal, dept store or skyscraper types.

The 12 business cards score victory points when built. They come in three types, cafes, retail, and two hotels.

The passenger cards score points when certain conditions are met. For example, 2 points for each municipal station on the line.

Players have their own markers; station, train, and action markers. The train markers go onto spaces around the board, marking the start and finish of their rail lines. The action markers go on an action board, which sets player order. In the round, players move their markers to select their actions in the round.

Players can select a business action, draw business cards and select the one they want, passing the remaining cards to other players who selected the same action. Being able to build a mix of businesses can earn bonus points at the end.

Players can then build out their rail line from hand cards dealt at the start and place a station marker. Completing lines allows a player to recover their markers. After this, some additional actions can be triggered, such as building tunnels.

Then conditions are checked for four open passenger cards. If a card is satisfied, players can score points, and the card is discarded. A fourth card is drawn, until no more are available.

The players action markers are moved back to determine the turn order, and rail cards are dealt back to each player and the game continues.

When the map is filled out, the game ends and players calculate their final scores. The most points wins the game for the best subway network builder.
user summary
mechanics: Action Drafting, Closed Drafting, Network and Route Building, Turn Order: Claim Action

name: Chindit Game
description:
A simple game representing a small group of Chindits trying to reach their base after a mission deep in enemy territory.

The game does not use figures all you need is a piece of paper a pen and a pack of playing cards including the jokers.

Quick and fun to play a game usually lasts less than 10 minutes.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Open Drafting, Paper-and-Pencil, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Once Upon A Crime
description: Once Upon a Crime is a party game based on the new "criminal storytelling" mechanic that combines deduction, bluffing and "StoryTelling" in a crime scenario. A player invents a crime by connecting a suspect, a motive, a weapon and a location using the cards on the table and reveals a single clue: who died. The other players must deduce the correct combination by choosing among 4 suspects, 4 motives, 4 weapons and 4 locations. But one or more of the players might be criminals, and they will try to trick them without getting caught.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Fantasy, Murder/Mystery

name: Beat Unemployment!
description:
Players play as a miner, a teacher, a shipworker, an engineer, a shopkeeper, or a company executive. The objective of the game is to not become unemployed. The game board is a circular track with Pay As You Lose and Survival cards placed in two separate decks in the center.

Players take turns rolling dice and moving a Monetarist Fiend playing piece around the board, landing on either a job space or a PAYL space. If it lands on a job space, players pay tax to the Cosmetic Economic Policies Fund according to each occupation provided in a table in the rules booklet. If it lands on a job space that is the player's own, then he/she is paid by the other players. If a player lands on a PAYL space, he/she takes a PAYL card and performs the actions on the card.

—user summary
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Level 7 [Omega Protocol]: Prototype Energy Weapon Promo
description:
This is a promotional kit card for Level 7 [Omega Protocol]. It was included with Level 7 [Invasion].

It provides an additional kit card with the following ability: Roll an additional red die for all your attacks made with your basic ranged weapon. A commando can have only one copy of this kit card.

This card can be included in the kit card deck during setup.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Horror, Miniatures, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Player Elimination, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Cosmic Exodus
description:
Cosmic Exodus is a strategic area control game for 2-6 players.

Each player takes on the role of a faction leaving earth with the aim of conquering the rest of the system. Along the way players will collect resource cards, and spend them to build space base's, move or warp their command ship to new planets and moons, and complete hidden objective cards.

The player with the most victory points - scored by planetary occupation and hidden objective missions - is the winner.

—description from the publisher
categories: Exploration, Science Fiction, Space Exploration, Territory Building
mechanics: Action Queue, Push Your Luck, Resource to Move

name: Philosopher: Game to Evolve Humanity
description:
Philosopher is a card game in which you discuss subjects with friends & family that may not come up in small talk. Some subjects are serious, some controversial, some esoteric, some funny, etc.
The primary deck includes 50 Topic cards and 150 viewpoint cards.
This is a deep conversational game, a profound adventure for the evolution of humanity. Go beyond the surface to know yourself, others & life better.

Games shift as players evolve and grow their life philosophies. The dynamic of the group will mold the trajectory of the game. Rotate from playing the PHILOSOPHER (the person’s whose turn it is) and the DEVOTEES (other players).

Examples of Topics are Angels, Magic, Ghosts, Atlantis, Dreams.

—description from the designer

name: Lights! Camera! Actors!
description:
Each card has 5 actors who have all appeared in the same movie. Guess the movie after the first actor is called, you get 5 points. After two actors, you get 4 points. Points diminish until it gets down to the last actor. Guess the movie after all 5 actors are named, you get 1 point.

To start the game, assign a person to keep score. Randomly pick one person to start the game. They pick the first card and read the first actor's name. They slowly read down the list of actors until either someone guesses the correct movie-- for which they are given the associated amount of points or they get to the end of the actor list without an answer. Either way, the card is put in the opposite end of the box and play moves on clockwise to the next person. Game ends when someone hits a pre-determined score milestone.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia

name: Star Fleet Battles: Captain's Log #33
description:
I have nightmares of the Juggernaut, and I have never seen one.

Released in June 2006, this Captain’s Log issue supports Star Fleet Battles, Federation Commander, and Federation & Empire. “Snap Count,” by Stephen V. Cole, has the appearance of Juggernaut Beta in Federation territory. Can Star Fleet, combined with the Federation Police and National Guard, defend Arcturus? “The Silence of the Dead,” by Randy O. Green, follows a Romulan ship that finds a derelict alien vessel in Tholian territory.

In addition to the story, History includes information on Tholian patrol corvettes and destroyers, with a class history of the latter, along with details on the Klingon Empire Security Service and the G1 gunboat.

As is usual, Communications informs readers about the company’s activities. Captain’s Log #32 and Federation Commander: Klingon Attack have after-action reports. The company laid out its plans for new print releases and metal miniatures for the coming year, including new materials for Federation Commander. There are questions and answers about submissions to ADB. The Input Guide has information about the style sheet that ADB follows. Proposals for Star Fleet Battles are presented. Admiral Growler answers SFB questions. More “Why” questions get answered. There is a page of filk songs.

Federation Commander has prototype rules for the Lyrans’ expanding spheres. There is a page of tactics papers. The three following scenarios appear:

The First Battle of Juggernaut Beta (Juggernaut Beta against anyone who wants to fight it),
Starhunt, the Stolen Freighters (Orion pirates and police), and
the Battle of Juggernaut Alpha (Juggernaut Alpha faces the “allies”) provide challenges for Federation Commander players.


This issue includes six scenarios for Star Fleet Battles. * SL246, Stand at Arcturus, is based on the story “Snap Count.”

SL247, Tentative Response, is set in the Magellanic Galaxy and pits Maghadim against the Baduvai.
SL248, Different Romulans, set during the Early Years, involves an encounter between the Vulcans and Gorns.
SL249, And None Shall Pass, is set in the Omega Octant and is a two-way battle between the Loriyill and Drex. A three-way version allows a third player to fly the Chlorophon ship.
SL250, A Dark and Stormy Day, has the Hydrans facing the Vudar.
SL251, Who Ordered the PFs?, a battle station’s PFs are absent, but a tug is on the way with replacements. Will the tug get the gunboats to the battle station in time without being destroyed itself?


Database articles include battlegroups designed with 1,00 points and the required use of a tug or light tactical transport if the empire didn’t have a tug. There is an article on the sun snake. SFB campaigns get a new rule for casual cargo storage. The Fast Patrol ship campaign is updated. There is a guide for Tholians to convert captured foreign ships to fit into Tholian fleets and vice versa.

The Tactics section has “Fog of War 4” by Jim Hart. The primer focuses on the Magellanic empires, exploring this new region’s standard tactics and counter-tactics. There are two pages of term papers.

The Venues section covers Star Fleet Command, SFB On-Line, playing by email, Galactic Conquest, Star Fleet Warlord, Prime Directive (with a look at Tholian biology), and Star Fleet Battle Force.

Federation & Empire has a status update along with rules and rulings, Q&A, and proposals. There are two pages of tactical notes. There is a new scenario, (674) The Long Distance War.

New ships are added for Star Fleet Battles. Everyone gets the civilian planetary operations base. The Federation gets the following destroyer variations: emergency management ship, Middle Years destroyer, deckhouse destroyer, deckhouse light carrier, deckhouse destroyer transport, heavy destroyer, heavy destroyer carrier, heavy destroyer transport, heavy destroyer minesweeper, and heavy commando transport.
The Tholians get the scout destroyer and “White Widow” destroyer carrier, both destroyer variants. They also get SSDs for the following captured ships: Federation police cutter, Romulan police ship, Orion Light Raider, and Klingon G2 gunboat. Juggernaut Beta from the cover story gets its SSD. Federation Commander gets new ship cards for the Lyran Jaguar war cruiser, Hydran Mongol medium cruiser, WYN war cruiser, and ISC light cruiser. These four ships are in fleet scale.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Infrastructure
description:
You've been charged with tailored development of your city, improve the infrastructure while aiming to be the most successful administrator. Players take turns placing tiles on a 5x5 board after which points are scored according to each players target scoring pad.
Player with most victory points emerges as the winning administrator.

—description from the designer

name: Nuclear Escalation: New Cards
description: Unofficial expansion consisting of six new cards for Nuclear Escalation that appeared in Space Gamer magazine (Issue 74 - May 1985)
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Modern Warfare, Negotiation

name: If you're lost you can look and you will find me // Time after time
description:
A 2 player game of love and time travel...

You have lived a life of time distorted. The days you live are not in chronological order. One day you might be 5 years old, learning to tie your shoe for the first time. You sleep, and awake the next day as a young adult, at a job you suddenly know (or remember?) how to do.

It’s exciting! Never a dull moment, every sensation feels fresh and new. You get to experience firsts again and again. There is no such thing as monotony.

But recently, your days have all had one thing in common. One person is always there. Even though you are living your relationship out of order, it is clear that you will love this person dearly (or perhaps you already do).

For the first time, you feel a desire to change this time-hopping life of yours and live linearly. You want to experience life with this person, to build and share the same memories together.

So now begins a conscious choice. You have to stabilize, to break free of the chaotic whirlpool of time you have found yourself tossed about it, and find calmer waters. You’re not even sure if it’s possible.

As you drag yourself towards a linear timeline, you can feel it take a toll on your body and mind. You’ve never lived time in order before, can you even handle it?

So many questions, so many unknowns. But what you do know is that you have to try, you really, really want to try. And you can sense that they do too.

Play this game when you want to feel very soft, share emotional intimacy, and maybe cry a little.

"Playing the game"


On your first turn, flip the card your token is already on face up
On subsequent turns, move your token to an adjacent (not
Read the prompt that corresponds to your card, answering the questions it poses
Note down any affects on your Time Sickness. Some cards will give you Time Sickness, others will heal it.
The aim of the game is for both players to move their tokens to the Joker card, stabilizing themselves and gaining the ability to live time linearly.

name: Admirals:  A Game of Fleet Actions in the Golden Age of Fighting Sail
description:
Admirals is a game which recreates, in a stylized fashion, the movements and interactions of fleets of sailing warships during the late 17th, 18th, and early 19th centuries. The purpose is to allow the player to take the role of the commander of a fleet of sailing warships and explore the choices and challenges which faced his historical counterpart.

Mechanics of this game are simple enough for a single player to command dozens of ships, while exploring the challenges faced by commanders in controlling a fleet of sailing warships in battle.

Turn sequence:
I. Movement Phase
II. Boarding Phase
III. Signals Phase
IV. Repair Phase

–description from the rulebook
categories: Age of Reason, American Revolutionary War, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Nautical, Pike and Shot, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Simulation

name: Battles For a Dungeon
description:
Welcome to the forest of Viaud, a forgotten place with a dungeon in its center. The rediscovery of this dungeon and the treasures it conceals has led to an influx of many peoples to take control of it.
Everyone has established their camp on the edge of the forest, ready to do battle, to settle a new economy and to reign on the ways to establish their power in this place. Skirmishes will take place, the most courageous peoples will dare to build outposts, will recruit units as close as possible to the dungeon and their opponents.
Each people has its special abilities, a season that makes it stronger, but how long will the current season last and when will yours come? No one can master these elements. At each turn, you will discover a punctual, ephemeral power, to be optimized as best as possible to develop yourself or fight your opponents!

Battles For A Dungeon is a strategy and placement game. As in all the games created by Mathieu Roussignol, the freedom of the players is huge, your choices have a strong impact on the other players’ strategies, no dice are to be rolled, the luck is present but very limited. You will find here an easy accessibility for a game including a lot of possible strategies. Peoples have perfectly balanced asymmetric powers/characteristics, so that everyone can play as he wants and has the same chance to win the game!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Queue, Area Movement, Investment, King of the Hill, Simulation, Zone of Control

name: Farbsprung
description: Farbsprung is a Pachisi-like game with color dice instead of normal dice. Accordingly, the path for the figures is designed with colour dots. Counting is not yet necessary here.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Das Spiel der Werbung
description:
In the Das Spiel der Werbung ("Game of Advertising"), the players each run an advertising agency with which they have to collect 50 medals as quickly as possible.

The players move their figures across the board with 2 dice and can move onto budget fields or event fields. On "budget" fields they receive a "budget" card and thus medals if they get through the "pitch" (answer a question correctly, solve an advertising task, etc.) and can pay the presentation costs. On event fields, cards are drawn and you can win or lose money and medals.

The questions included in the game require a basic knowledge of the advertising industry.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Under Construction
description:
As the new foreman, you have a specific goal: get those buildings constructed! Only to do that you have to find ways of maximizing your efforts with the Construction Vehicles, which end up all over the yard and depending when you use them, they will provide different bonuses.

Plot out the construction of your Buildings by collecting materials, even off turn. Each Building has a special power and can only be constructed once. Often points are gained at times when Buildings are constructed, which can lead to intriguing timing to maximize the value those buildings will earn.

Take care to use abilities to shift dice, even to rows they wouldn’t normally be in, finding the Bulldozer in the Dump Truck’s row can show of some truly versatile play! Plus dice remain where they are until they are used, only then are they rerolled. Did you set yourself up for a great play later on or will your opponents pounce on it first?

Under Construction is a game of utilizing Construction Vehicles to gain their favor and also resources to erect buildings. Buildings create an engine to further utilize the Construction Vehicles. In the end, the player who did both the best will walk away victorious. Watch for clever combos and Vehicles moving outside of their lanes to create chaos and new opportunities.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Marburg-Spiel
description:
The players roll their pieces along a given path through the small town of Marburg and are surprised by events on certain fields along the way. In addition, there is some information about the sights of Marburg. The first player to reach the exact finishing square wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Events, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Tomadaca
description:
Clay poker chips are stacked on a central, circular wooden board in 3 stacks of 16 chips of randomly mixed colors (5 colors, RED, BLUE, GREEN, YELLOW, BLACK). Traditional values are generally assigned to the colors (i.e. RED = $5), but some color values can change for particular players based on various bonuses awarded.

Players take turns with opportunities to TAKE one poker chip for themselves from the top of any one stack or GIVE one to another player from the top of any one stack. The latter action is only constructive for winning because on the GIVER's next turn, it awards him the bonus of taking exactly 2 chips from the top of any combination of stacks (or 2 from the top of the same stack); once per round they may even take 3 chips in the same manner.

Play proceeds until rounds equal to the number of players are played. Each round, values are tallied; the final accumulative highest grand total tally wins.

This is mostly a strategy game with not much luck, except for the initial set-up that offers a bit of luck; this is balanced by letting each player start a round in a game.

TOMA: Take; DACA: Give (in Spanish)
mechanics: Induction, Once-Per-Game Abilities, Score-and-Reset Game, Variable Set-up

name: Hades Item-Night God: LARP
description:
Goal of the Game:
Players need to work together to get a perfect ENDing. Then convince the City God (Cheng Huang) to agree it.

A player plays as Yuelao (Chinese Cupid) to be the host.

Phase 1: Day Patrol
There are memories in 13 rooms. Players owns limit joss sticks to explore different 13 rooms to get clue. If players explore 8 rooms, they will goes to phase 2.

Phase 2: Night Watch
Players has to discuss with each other to get own clue in 60 minutes.

Phase 3: Trial
There are different characters for each player. Player will provide information from previous phase to get the final ENDing.

name: Hades Item: Board game
description:
Goal of the game: Players are the guards of City God (Cheng Huang) and try to arrest the phantoms fleeing everywhere.

Shuffle the Phantoms- Fleeing tiles and distribute 3 tokens to every player. Then the game bigins.

Phase 1: Night Watch
There are 9 actions for all players. Different actions costs different arresting tiles. Players owns limit arresting tiles to do actions. If player runs out of arresting tiles or want to stop at time, then it's next player's turn.

Phase 2: Night Patrol
Players has do decide to arrest or not.

Phase 3: Night Trial
If the players arrest the Phantoms- Fleeing successfully, he will get the Phantoms- Fleeing tiles. If not, player will lose arresting tiles

Phase 4: Day Patrol
If player catch correct Phantoms- Fleeing, the player wins.

name: Hades Item: Six paths – Puzzle book
description:
Goal of the game:
Player has to solve the puzzle to get the final truth!

There are different clue in 10 post cards. Player has to use the cooper coins and compass to get corresponding words or pictures. If you can go through to 10th Puzzle, and figure it out, you win the game

name: Human Compost
description:
A 15mm miniatures game of mutant warfare set in the post apocalyptic future.

One of four players take turns moving through a barren wasteland looking for the remnants of previous humans to feed to the toxic pits. After acquiring the correct combination of human remnants, players spawn one of 4 large mutants that can be used to destroy your opponent.

Solo rules allow a player to fight against one or many opponents depending on the desired difficulty.

Game is played on a hexagonal map and includes 4 main 15mm figures, 4 mutant monsters and 4 auxiliary characters with optional terrain pieces.

name: Li.. La.. Löffelspiel
description:
The players are supposed to spoon out of the plate as quickly as possible all the vegetable pieces that can be seen on the card that has just been turned over. But it's not as easy as it sounds, because the spoons have joints and bend exactly when you don't need them, making you lose the carrot you just picked up very quickly. For smaller children who want to play along, you can also push the spoon together and thus make the handle immovable.

—user summary;;

name: Karten-Würfeln
description: Who manages to get the most cards through lucky dice rolling and clever calculations?

name: BladeShift Worldsiege
description:
Dynamic with plenty of depth for experienced re-players, BladeShift is a game in which players take on the guise of a skilled Fighter on a quest to collect 3 remaining elemental affinity seals from the realm of The Shift.
These Seals brought together would allow one to save their realm from the abominations waiting to invade, should they fail their quest, or to mark The Shift realm as a first conquest...

As players progress and level up through the dungeon, so too do the challenging monsters they'll have to face in efforts to return the seal to their gateway.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Fantasy, Fighting
mechanics: Action Points, Critical Hits and Failures, Die Icon Resolution, Finale Ending, Modular Board, Trading

name: Décadex
description:
The game board is a grid of colored numbers (1-4) with intersecting lines between the numbers. Players take turns placing 4 rings each on the board, and then moving those rings to achieve a total of 10. To win the game, the four rings must be placed on four numbers of four different colors or 2 pairs of identical colors.

—user summary

name: Tabloid Charades
description:
Charades based on actual tabloid stories!

Tabloid Chardes is intended as a light-hearted diversion, not a game of heated competition. Teams work with, not against, one another. A member of TEAM 1 acts out a charade on his team card while TEAM 2 guesses, then a member of TEAM 2 acts while TEAM 1 guesses.

The charades in each round round do not have to be performed in any particular order. Each performer is free to act out the charade of his choice, and may seek the help of other team members if stuck.

The game has been designed to play in one evening.

VARIATIONS
1. Instead of the performer choosing the charade he will act out, have the other team pick a number.
2. Certain charades might be taken on as a group project, with team members acting together to achieve the desired effect.

name: Shift
description:
The game board is a plastic six by six square grid which allows for the sliding of pieces. Players take turns placing their counters (20 each) on the board. Players are allowed to "shift" rows of counters to block their opponent's attempt to get 5 in a row.

The game is made in Hong Kong.

name: Smack Talk Showdown: Lewd ADDitude
description:
The Lewd ADDitude expansion for Smack Talk Showdown includes 100 new NSFW cards to give your smack talking action that extra edge.

Lewd ADDitude is the NSFW expansion to Smack Talk Showdown. Take your smack talk to the next level, but maybe put the kids to bed first.

It can be played as a standalone game or be combined with the base version of Smack Talk Showdown.

—description from the publisher

name: Travelus: Connect
description:
This is one of the eight games built on a flexible and unique modular game design that makes playing numerous games with a set of shared components possible and sold in a boxed set.

As a seasoned traveler, you reap unforgettable experiences around the Continents. While you enjoy visiting places with spring-like weather, islands surrounded by turquoise water, and peaceful oases with the loveliest sunsets, you relish the experiences and connections with the people you meet throughout your journey that enhance your perspective and enrich your world.

To win, all you have to do is to collect a minimum of 3 Passport Stamps and the most Connection cards. You start with 1 Passport Stamp collected and the game ends when someone gets 4. Each Traveler who has at least 3 Passport Stamps then adds up the Connection cards they have. You may not be the one who got the most Passport Stamps, but you could still have made more connections and win!

On your turn, you roll a die and move the number of spaces rolled. When you land on the Passport Office, you can collect that Continent's Passport Stamp, using the Capital and Connection cards collected along the way. Getting connections is as simple as landing on the space, then reading and voting on a statement. You get a connection when the majority agrees with you! You will need money for expenses and to pay for Passport Stamps. Luckily, there are cards that can help you in numerous ways - by moving you across continents in one move, winning a lottery, and even getting free Passport Stamps! But watch out because they also can land you in jail or incur unexpected expenses.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Events, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Modular Board, Open Drafting, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading, Variable Set-up, Voting

name: Visions of Derna: The Raid on Tasimboko – A scenario for Chain of Command
description:
This is a one-off scenario based on the US Marine Raiders and Parachutists attack on the Japanese held village of Tasimboko during the Guadalcanal campaign.
Like their predecesors before them near Tripoli, lead Edson's Raiders in seizing critical Japanese supplies or defend the village as the IJA from these pirates!

The scenario is designed to be used with Too Fat Lardies' Chain of Command, however it can be readily adapted to your preferred WWII miniature ruleset.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Travelus: Excavate
description:
Scientists have made an incredible discovery - a giant deposit of a new vital precious metal in the center of Destinarc. One ounce of this material can power a huge city for decades. The discovery is lying close enough to the surface to be mined, but too far down to be found using current exploration methods so it takes a squad of 8 different types of mining and metal experts to work together. To win a contract to mine, you are expected to lead your squad through this expedition and be the first to arrive at the mine.

Your mission is to find the fastest and safest way to get your 8 members from 8 Domains to the mine.

Each member starts their journey alone. On your turn, you roll a die and move one of your members the same number of spaces. You can get closer and quicker by going through tunnels. But wait! Competing squads may be there blocking your way forward. And if they land on you, they can send you back to where you started!

Mercifully, there are power drills that can help you, but getting them is not an easy task. Prospect cards may help but they may also hinder so you are taking a chance each time you pick one up.

This is one of the eight selected games built on a flexible and unique modular game design that makes playing numerous games with a set of shared components possible.
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Events, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Pick-up and Deliver, Race, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading, Variable Set-up

name: Pursuit of Victory
description:
Europe, 1805. Emperor Napoleon prepares his La Grande Armée for a perilous invasion of the United Kingdom. Only the might of the Royal Navy stands between him and the British Isles – that and Napoleon’s own meddling in international politics. Austria and Russia, thrust into the welcoming embrace of Britain, mobilize their forces... Will the British forge a Grand Coalition and annihilate Napoleon’s armies in one decisive battle? Or will the Emperor force his enemies to submit after a series of dazzling campaigns?

Pursuit of Victory is a 2-player game of military conquest and diplomatic realignment, of bold action and meticulous planning, playable in a couple of hours. Napoleon will have to face an ever-shifting combination of European powers, consider the fate of Spanish and Polish people, and keep an eye on small, but mobile British forces. Britain will have to contain Napoleon’s ambitions, stoke the fire of Spanish insurrection, subsidize their allies and wait for an opportunity to strike a crucial blow against the French.
In Pursuit of Victory players simultaneously play two cards. One for its initiative value and up to two actions, and the other one for its various military and diplomatic effects. Each player has a hand of 10 cards and playing any given card makes it unavailable for next 2-3 turns. And there are always the two national questions looming ahead. The French can recreate Poland and take over Spain, but will the gains outweigh the costs?

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Retrieval, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Movement Points, Simulation, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Voll der Hammer
description:
The players are do-it-yourselfers and renovate three of their rooms (bathroom, kitchen, bedroom) and their garden. You score points for DIY work and spending as little money as possible. The first player to reach the garden shed at the end of the course finishes the game; the player with the most points wins. Whoever's turn it is rolls the dice and either moves the piece the full distance or moves at least one square and uses part of the points for actions, either working or saving money. To work, you must have bought tools at the hardware store beforehand. Tools can also wear out. You can only work in one room at a time; if you score a room, you get points for it. If you score earlier, you get more points.

—user summary

name: Ready 2 Help
description:
The game that teaches you how to...
Stay Safe
Stay Calm
Get Help
Give Info
Give Care

Brought to you by FEMA.

This is a small family card game that the winner is the first to collect five emergency cards.

During a turn an emergency card is flipped over and read aloud. Players then take turns playing Skill or Take Action cards from their hand. If the player has enough cards to complete the requirements of the emergency then they collect the card and play passes to the next player. Hand limit of 5 cards.

name: Dunginoes
description:
Explore the dungeon and look for secret passages in this no-print-just play dominoes game.

Themed Dominoes and rules are available on the designer's website.

name: Polizze
description:
Polizze is a simple promotional game by Raiffeisenbank in which each player moves his piece forward on his own track based on a puzzle result. On the square reached, he uncovers one of 2 cards, which earns either positive, negative or no points at all. If a player reaches the finish line, the player with the most points wins. Though, one tactic could be to send a player who has already collected many minus points to the finish line.

—user summary

name: Magic Trolls: End of the Rainbow
description: A children's game based on the Magic Troll Babies / Magic Troll Warriors cartoons and toy lines of the early 1990s. In Magic Trolls: End of the Rainbow, players aim to get rid of all of their Magic Troll cards by rolling and moving around the Troll road while playing cards. This family fun & friendly game will help younger Troll enthusiasts practice colors and numbers, but is fun enough for the whole family to enjoy the magic of Trolls.

name: Trivial Pursuit Coasters
description: These 20 coasters featuring 120 trivial pursuit questions are the perfect addition to any game night. Featuring classic categories, these traditional carded style coasters are the perfect way to choose a starting player, keep trivia night light-hearted, or to spice up any game night.

name: Scrabble Coasters
description: Spice up game night, or simply show off your love of Scrabble with new coasters. This set contains 26 carded style coasters depicting all the letter tiles on one side, and the classic board spaces on their reverse. Add a little Scrabble flair to your game night, or use them as a quick mini-game to choose starting players or transition between games. The coasters are dealt out evenly between players who must try to make the highest scoring word they can using either side of their coasters. Don't have any vowels? No worries, simply use your coasters to give the edge to one of your friends.

name: The Game of Gettysburg & Adams County
description: A Monopoly-style game depicting landmarks and famous sites of south-central Pennsylvania around Gettysburg and Adams County. This is a simple Monopoly clone in the same vein as Wheeler Dealer, Make-Your-Own-Monopoly, or any Hometown Promotion game. What makes this game unique is its wonderful art and photos of all your favorite spots around Gettysburg and the surrounding county, sponsored by the Gettysburg area Rotary club.

name: Our Special Friends Visit Harrisburg
description: Sponsored for and produced by ARC (Association for Retarded Citizens of Dauphin County) and printed by Y/Z printing of Elizabethtown PA, Our Special Friends Visit Harrisburg is a light-hearted family game where players roll and move through the county to the capital in Harrisburg PA. Featuring interesting art of familiar places around Harrisburg, this simple family game is an easier and more colorful local themed game than games like All About Harrisburg, published around the same time.

name: München live
description:
Munich live includes questions from 5 categories (nightlife, lifestyle, hotels, shopping and culinary). Furthermore, you have to assess the other players on these topics.
The highlight of the game are 4 champagne glasses in which the victory points (glass marbles) are collected. The player who fills his glass first wins the game.

—user summary
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Track Movement

name: York Clubhouse Golf
description:
Clubhouse style golfing in the comfort of your own home, brought to you by York Air Conditioning. Printed and published in Chicago by Stephens, Biondi, & De Cicco Inc. for York Air Conditioning in 1962, York Clubhouse Golf features an 18-hole course for you and up to 5 others to enjoy. York Clubhouse Golf uses pushpins to mark ball locations and a variety of dice to swing with including:
White - shot direction and accuracy
Red - driving
Yellow x2 - used together for chipping and pitching
Blue - mid to low ranges
Green x2 - used together from outer green putting, or singly for inner green

—user summary

name: Treis Kai Deka
description:
The players use game tokens with printed on card symbols. The tokens may be combined with wooden shells of four different colors (white, black, red, green). The colors are used to represent player colors or different values.

There are 7 different games in 25 variants possible, mostly adapted from Halma and Asalto. In most games the players have to get from one corner of the game board to another corner. The seven Games are:

1. Turnierspiele
2. Besetzungsspiele
3. Nullspiele
4. Metadorspiele
5. Angriff und Verteidigung
6. Kleeblattspiele
7. Doppellauf

name: Roller Ball
description:
A player places a ball in the start position and proceeds to guide the ball through the maze using two control knobs which tilt the maze in all directions. If the ball falls into a hole, the score is the number beside the hole. The other players then play, highest score wins.

—user summary

name: Bolt Action: Banzai! Japanese Starter Army
description:
The contents of the Banzai! Japanese Starter Army box were based on the following Bolt Action 1,000 point Imperial Japanese army list:

Rikugun Chui (First Lieutenant) and two soldiers Regular* 95 pts
IJA Infantry Squad Regular (10 men with SMG and LMG)* 123 pts
